Praefatio.	Prologue.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I completed for you, O Son, this book which is the last of medical knowledge with its supplement, and I reached its end through its explanations and clarifications, it seemed fitting to me to complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of practice, that is surgery, by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since manual operation has been prostrated in our region and time, and has altogether been deprived until its knowledge may have perished, and its trace been cut off, and nothing remains of it but small descriptions in ancient books which were altered by hands, and error and hesitation occurred to them until their intentions were closed, and its way was lengthened, it seemed fitting to me to revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise therein according to the way of explanation, clarification, and abbreviation: and that I may come with forms of instruments for cautery, and other tools of operation, through addition of clarifications and expediting what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why no good artisan of it with his own hand is found in our time is because the art of medicine is long, and its author must exercise himself beforehand therein in the science of anatomy which Galen narrated until he knows the joints of members, their forms, their connection and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, sinews, their number and course, and pulsating veins and quiet ones, and their outlets.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of this Hippocrates said that 'a name with a name is much, but with work it is little, especially in the art of hand.'
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	But we have already spoken about him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since whoever is not knowing what we have said about anatomy will certainly fall into error whereby people are killed, as I have seen many of those who claim to be formed in this knowledge and boast about it without knowledge and experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That is because I saw a foolish physician cut open an abscess on the neck of a woman and sever certain arteries in her neck: wherefore blood flowed from the woman until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who presumed to remove a stone from a man who had grown old with it, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He went forth therefore unto him, and drew out the stone together with part of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	But I myself had already been called unto to remove it, and I saw that because of the size of the stone and the condition of the sick man, he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who received payment from a certain Duke of our land because of his medicine: and it happened that there was a fracture in the leg of a black eunuch who was with him near the heel. And the physician hastened with his ignorance, and bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong ligatures without allowing the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he dismissed him according to his desire.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he let him go for some days and ordered him not to loose the bandage: and so it remained until his leg and foot became gangrenous and were destroyed.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called unto him, and hastened to loose the bandage: and quietness followed, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the gangrene had already become confirmed in the member, and I could not check it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	So therefore the corruption spread throughout the member until he died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who punctured a cancerous abscess, and it became ulcerated afterwards, until its wickedness grew great with its owner.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	This is because when an abscess is pure from black bile humor, then it should not be pierced with iron at all unless it is on a member that can tolerate it being completely cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, O Son, it is necessary for you to know that an operation with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, an operation associated with health, and an operation with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already indicated in every place of this book where an operation comes that causes fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of this and avoid it: so that fools may not find a way to speak about it and bring dishonor upon it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take measure with care and protection, and your patients with ease and steadfastness. Use the better path leading by God's grace to health and praiseworthy success. Leave behind terrible illnesses that are difficult to cure, and free yourselves from that which causes you fear, lest doubt should enter upon your faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining for your glory, and more sublime in this world, and finally for your profit.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has already said in certain of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat an illness badly, lest you be called bad physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now however, I have divided this Treatise into three chapters:
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Concerning the cautery with fire and the cautery with sharp medicine, arranged and ordered from head to foot, and forms of instruments and implements of the cautery: and all that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Concerning section and perforation, bloodletting and wounds, and extraction of arrows, and similar things: and all arranged and ordered with forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Concerning restoration and reduction, and treatment of dislocations, and similar things: all arranged and ordered from head to foot with forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Concerning the benefit and harm of cautery: and in which constitutions it is suitable, and at what time: and if with iron, or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I mention the operation concerning it, it is necessary that I should speak of the benefits and harms of it, and in which constitution it should be exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore that the discourse concerning the benefit and harm of cautery is a long and subtle science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Many wise men have spoken about it and they disagreed; but for me, a few words will suffice, lest I prolong (the discussion).
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore that cautery is beneficial for every constitution, whether it has matter or not; except for two constitutions, namely a hot constitution without matter and a dry constitution without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But concerning the hot and dry constitution with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some said that cautery is beneficial for it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of that, namely that cautery is not suitable for an illness that arises from heat and dryness: because the nature of fire is heat, and it is unsuitable to heal an illness that is hot and dry with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of that said: by cautery there is benefit for every hot and dry illness that occurs in human bodies; because when you compare the body of a man and its moistures to the constitution of fire, you find the body of a man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I myself say through his words: for it has been proven true to me many times through experience.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	But nevertheless it is not fitting that anyone should approach this matter except one who has already been proven and trained in the final chapter of Cautery Practice, and has known the diversity of human constitutions, and the disposition of illnesses within themselves, and their causes, accidents, and duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But as for other constitutions, there is no fear over them. And especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all doctors have agreed on these matters, and they do not disagree about using cautery to benefit them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that the secret of healing by cautery with fire and its good quality is such that it burns only the member being cauterized, and does not harm any other connected member unless there is a slight injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches that which is distant from members, and perhaps causes difficult-to-heal illnesses to occur in a member, and perhaps even kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, due to its fineness and good substance, does not do this unless there is an excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	But we have learned this through experience due to the length of our service and study with this art, and our diligence in searching for the truth of things. And therefore I excuse myself for the length of this discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not for the fact that this book of mine does not allow me to reveal to you the secret hidden in fire and the quality of its operation on bodies for driving out illnesses, which demonstrates by philosophical proof that it sharpens your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my sons, that they disagree at the time when cautery is to be performed, and they set a better time for the truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cautery is appropriate at all times: for the harm that occurs because of time is submerged in the benefit that is drawn along with cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cautery is performed because of pains from necessary, strong, and urgent ailments that do not tolerate delay; for it is feared that a greater harm may result from them than the slight harm caused by waiting for the right time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not fall into the error, my sons, which is held only by the common people and foolish physicians, that there is no return to health after an ailment has been cured by cautery; they assert this consequence, but it is not so; for cautery is employed only in place of medicine which alters the complexion and dries up the moistures which are the cause of pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Nevertheless, cautery exceeds medicine in the swiftness of its cure, and the strength of its operation, and the vehemence of its power; it is possible that an ailment may return at some later time according to the constitution of the patient, and the location and nature of the ailment, and its strength; and what accumulates in his body from superfluities in him, and what reaches it through food and similar causes, unless he becomes ill with one in which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle ailment in a member with few superfluities and moistures, such as the pain of a toothache, for example, may not return.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	However, the common belief that cautery is the last resort of medicine is not entirely accurate. People think that there is no cure after cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	On the contrary, cautery is not really the last resort of medicine; rather, it is used only when other methods of treatment have failed to bring about a cure.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than with iron, and they said this because of the fineness of gold and its exalted nature. They also said that it does not cause pus at the site of the cautery.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true. For I have already proven that [cautery with gold] does not cause pus in some bodies without other complications.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And indeed cautery with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you use fire cautery with gold, it is not clear how much heat you are applying due to the redness of the gold. Moreover, if you increase the heat, the gold will melt in the fire and become liquefied.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman becomes confused by this. And for that reason, we use cautery with iron more quickly and accurately in our operations.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to the chapters, and ordered them from head to foot, so that whoever seeks something may find it easily.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	On the method of cauterizing: The head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here the cautery is useful for the lordship of humidity and coldness above the brain: which two are causes of madness and multitude of flows of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and multitude of sleep, and toothache, and sore throat, and universally all diseases that occur from coldness, such as paralysis, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is this: you should advise the patient to evacuate first with a cleansing solvent medicine for three nights or four, according to what the strength of the patient requires and their age and habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he has placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever therefore your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with a cauter.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then take the olive-oil cautery: of which this is the shape:
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with descent, as your hand is gradually tightened, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly remove your hand, and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	But if you see that now a quantity of alkiel has been released from the bone, or a quantity of zeuherbi, then raise your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the cautery with the same iron or another if it has cooled until you see the bones which I have told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water and sprinkle it on the spot, and let him rest for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Next, place upon it butter into which is soaked the mixture, and leave it there until the burn is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment tetrapharmacon until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They say that the more a wound remains open, the more pus it emits: therefore it is better and more helpful to keep it open.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them say that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone and held until something of the thickness of the bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then shave what has been burned from the bone, and then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that one must come with the cautery to the final point until it makes an impression on the bone like a brand or instrument for lettering: and they think that from this place vapors of the head escape, and the wound is left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But these two methods of cautery seem to me useful only for certain people according to their nature and temperament.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	I think it is better to leave it alone with care for its well-being.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by breaking its natural continuity; as we have seen in other members, especially when it has a weak nature. The first method of cautery seems to me safer and better, and I use it; therefore act with caution.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On the manner of cauterizing the head for headache.
Caput III.	Chapter Three.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic headache occurs and persists in a patient despite the use of medicines such as hyeres, cochis, caput-purgatives, oils, and emplasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with the cautery that I have described, and none of those remedies help: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is robust by nature and not weak, and a violent chill is found: then cauterize with another cautery beneath it slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize the horn of the head itself with the cautery, so that it does not penetrate the skin, and uncover as much bone as I have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with the cautery at the back of the head itself, in the place called 'the vessel': which is where the windpipe is placed, and raise your hand slightly there, without uncovering the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient finds great pain in this, different from the pain of all other head cauteries.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say that this cautery should be used in its place; and it is necessary that there should be a cautery for burning the horns of the head, and a finer one for burning the back of the head, which is also used for burning the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in headache, both with burning medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and stiffness occurs in part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is cleansed with medicines that purify it, and the rest of the treatment that I have described for the divisions of illnesses is administered, but nothing helps: then cautery is performed on it in two ways: either cauterization with burning acute medicine, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cautery with burning acute medicine is this: take one clove of garlic, peel it, and cut off its ends on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then incise the painful area in the temple with a wide lancet until there is made beneath the skin a place to hold the garlic.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it beneath the skin until it is hidden; then bind it with a suitable bandage of lint and leave it for fifteen hours. Then remove the garlic and let the wound remain open for two or three days. Afterwards, apply butter in which a piece of cotton has been immersed until pus forms. Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain medicines that burn, which I have written about in the twelfth book on burning medications.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cautery of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The form of the cautery used for fire is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called the 'Claw': because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, with some curvature and a small prominence in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand steady; you turn the iron gradually with speed, and let the amount that is burned be equal to the thickness of the skin.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand so that the artery below is not burnt, lest blood flow should occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then bathe the wound with salt water and apply it to the spot; leave it for three days. Then apply butter to the wound. Afterwards treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this half of the head with the second edge of the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	Beware of cutting the artery in this case, as it is not proper for an old wound.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in an old head wound.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating a head wound with what we have said about previous treatments and the divisions of illnesses, but the treatment does not help and you see that the illness is severe and that cautery with medicine or fire alone is insufficient, then take the cautery with the knife-like edge until it turns white. Then mark the spot of pain with a line whose length is half a fingerbreadth or roughly that amount. Then place your hand once and press it down until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	But you must take care to avoid the continuation of the jawbone that moves during chewing, lest the side or nerve that moves it be burned and cause spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And beware of bleeding from the artery that has been cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is fear in its cutting, especially for one who does not know what he is doing and is neither studious nor experienced. He may leave the procedure before it has even begun.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with a reminder about managing blood flow from an artery according to its method and location within this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	But if you see that the illness does not improve with this cautery and observe the patient's body unable to tolerate it in the middle of the head as we have described, then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, use the cautery with two knife-like edges that we mentioned in the chapter on arterial cautery.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cautery causes better burning and is more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When ear pain occurs due to cold and is treated with solvents and other remedies mentioned earlier but the pain does not go away, then cauterize it with fire using a cautery called 'the point,' which has this shape:
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make dots with it around the entire ear after igniting it, as it revolves: or around both if there is pain in both ears.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And lengthen the cautery from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the places with the hot iron; and let the amount of cautery be ten punctures in every ear, and almost that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the areas until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	About the manner of cauterizing in Torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture which is treated with cautery is only of kinds which occur from phlegm, according to what we said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cauterizing species that occurs from drying out and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this kind of torture with herbs, and purgatives, and gargarisings, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the infirm person with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and second a little lower from its time, and third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the infirm part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cautery is that you should cauterize with the cautery itself on the direct extremity of the upper ear under the horn of the head a little, and on the tympanum: whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And remove your hand with the cautery until it burns through half the thickness of the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species from a cutlery knife, whose form is shown above: but it should not be too thin, as you see; and it is necessary that there be excess thickness on it a little like a knife.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the areas with what was prescribed earlier until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	About the manner of cauterizing in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy is of long standing and the treatments we have described do not help, nor does your medication bring about any improvement, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries upon each horn of his head, and one cautery in the middle of his head as already mentioned, and another cautery at the back of his head according to what is described before: and the method of cautery should be as previously stated.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And also cauterize with a cautery upon the stomach bone, which is the last resort.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat him with what preceded [i.e., the previously mentioned treatments].
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterizing in the case of Paralysis (Obliquione).
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that firstly the patient be given a large dose of hyera (a medicine made from the dung of a black ox) and pills to purge the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Next, shave the whole head of the patient, and place upon the back of his head the plaster made from mustard described in the treatise on plasters: and apply it frequently.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For that indeed is the method of cautery: and do this according to the same order which I have described there [i.e., earlier in the treatise].
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is cured by it, that is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	But if not, then perform three cauteries on the back part of his head, descending from the upper part of his head to the lower part of his eye; and place between each cautery the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cautery with what preceded [i.e., the previously mentioned treatments].
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish to add more and the patient can tolerate it, then perform a cautery in the middle [of his head].
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	But if you wish to add still further, then cauterize him upon both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him until he is cured; and let the cautery be of olive-oil according to the shape which has been prescribed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing in the case of Paralysis and softening [of limbs].
Caput X.	Chapter X
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head using hyera, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Next, shave the head of the patient; then cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and cauterize every horn [temple] of the head, and cauterize behind it, and three times over the nape of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If the disease requires many mollifications of the body and the patient is tolerant but the illness is strong: then cauterize him four times with a cautery over the nape of his back, and the last one until it burns deeply into his skin, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat him until he is healed: and thus cauterize with oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	And how to cauterize for epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic is not cauterized unless his epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore it is necessary that you cleanse his brain first with hyera, and with the rest of the treatment which we have mentioned in the division: when the patient is great or is tolerant to accepting medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if it is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then gargarisms and cleansing chewables should be administered to him for many days before with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head; then cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what has preceded in method: and cauterize another on his occiput, and cauterize over every horn of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if the patient is strong and is tolerant then cauterize him with cauteries which I have mentioned in paralysis, and mollifications of the body over the nape of his neck and back: and let the cautery be oiled according to the method that has preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the patient is a child then place a fine cautery, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	And how to cauterize for melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted moistures and thick phlegm then cauterize him with cauteries which we have mentioned in paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is abundance flowing towards melancholy, and the body of the sick is moistened, then give him in drink that cleanses his brain according to what has preceded in division: then shave the head of the sick, and afterwards make a turban well made of linen like a crown.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of his head: and let the sick person sitting squarely be held from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	It is better made from old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a fire with moderate heat, which the finger can tolerate when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then pour it onto his head in a circle and let it sit until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the sick person once every week with the rest of his good regimen until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize him by making many small punctures around it, except where you hold your hand with the cautery: in fact, let there be a smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a cotton wick soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	Method of cauterizing in water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When it is declared to you that the beginning of water is in the eye by signs which I have mentioned in division, then begin and give the sick person drink with that which cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And protect him from all moistures, and make him sit in a bath for several days while fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to shave his head and cauterize him in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him over both temples with two cauteries if there is the beginning of water descending into both eyes at once, or on one side if there is the beginning of water in one eye: and cut off with a cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in breadth like the temples: and keep away from bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from him, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them off, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck under two bones with two cauteries extended at the end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	About the way of cauterizing old tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and continuous, and there are veins and arteries on top of them that are clearly visible on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is from cold and phlegmatic excesses: then cauterize with a cautery the same as I have described for the beginning of descending water, placing one cautery in the middle of the head, two cauteries over both temples, and two cauteries on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need additional caution, then carefully cauterize each side of the eye over the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	About the way of cauterizing for foul-smelling nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat that with what we have said about division and it does not help the treatment, then hurry and give him to drink cochlias three nights in a row: then shave his head and cauterize him with a middle-sized cautery using olive oil.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with a small cautery-shaped cautery on both eyebrows under the hair, a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And protect from the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	And how to cauterize for softening the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter Sixteen.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by sickness or moisture, then cauterize it with one cautery, like this crescent-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on every part; and they will become elongated in two times [i.e., periods]; and let the length of all the cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow; and do not place your hand last with the cautery, but rather according to the quantity that is burned, one-third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery according to this crescent-shaped manner of cauterizing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	And how to cauterize the eyelid when hairs grow inwards and prick the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter Seventeen.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery for this is of two kinds: either a cautery with fire, or a cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But before applying the cautery with fire, instruct the patient to remove his hairs, if he has them for that purpose, until they grow out and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if [the hairs] prick him at their origin, then compress his eyes with a bandage so that they do not move until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	And when they have grown out and become even, then place the head of the patient on your lap; next, mark the eyelid of his eyes with a hot iron, making the mark like the shape of a myrtle leaf; let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a cotton wick soaked in egg white or marshmallow gum on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then with fire, use this shaped cautery.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the mark you made gradually in many places until the skin surface burns completely like the proper shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the cure of your operation is: if you see the eyelid of the eye now contracting and the hairs raised at the point of entry into the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore lift up your hand then: and let him go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then put on him a poultice with butter until the slough is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if some of the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid softens: then cauterize that place again as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If the hairs are below: then cauterize them until they rise to their natural place and become even so that they do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	You should instruct the patient to let their hair grow until it reaches its full length and is even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make a pattern of the laurel leaf shape from paper.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Next, take an equal weight (uncia I) of known soap and unslaked lime, mix them thoroughly with care, so that it does not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take some of this mixture and spread it onto the paper pattern you made in the shape of a laurel leaf. Place it on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a cloth soaked in egg white, and have the patient's head resting in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	Place your index finger on the medication and press it gently for a moment.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And whenever the patient feels the medicine biting, move it gently, as its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	When the sensation of being bitten continues as described, then remove the medication and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	Once the biting sensation has ceased, remove the medication and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then observe whether the eyelid lifts up as it does when cauterized with fire or cut. If not, apply more medication to the area where it has not taken effect and darkened, until your procedure achieves the desired result and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place a cloth soaked in butter on it until the burned skin is healed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphanous ointment or another one until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And during the procedure, you must take the utmost care to ensure that no medication falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if the eyelid becomes softened after a few days and something from the hair falls into the eye, apply the medication again to that area where the eyelid has softened, as you did initially.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of the laurel leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that human eyes differ in size and weakness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, your consideration should be this: the path of righteousness is not hidden from him who strives for excellence in this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing in a tear duct fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula and it does not improve with what we have said about divisions of ailments, then it is necessary to cauterize it in this manner.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head on your lap and have an assistant hold it between their hands so that it does not move or shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a poultice soaked in albumen of egg or slippery elm mucilage over his eye. Then take the cautery whose shape is like this:
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be hollow like the shape of a swan's feather quill from one end to the other. And if you wish it to penetrate all the way to the other end, or if you wish it to slope upwards, then test it thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this hollow shape is best for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula if it is open and remove its pus and dry it out. And if it is not open then open it and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place on it the cautery which has been heated very well.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it with your hand against the cautery for a short time near the eye towards the nose so that your hand does not slip or disturb the patient. Then place the cautery in the fat of the eye and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you reach the beginning of your cautery up to the mouth, it will be well done.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice if necessary. And leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place cotton with butter and dress it with a drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days pass and it does not heal, then apply a sharp corrosive medicine until the bone is exposed. And scrape it according to what comes up in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for a fistula, which some first described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Pay attention to the location of the fistula and find it. Then place in its opening a thin cannula, that is, a fine tube, which has this shape.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the amount of a dram of melted lead, and hold your hand with good retention on the tube so that the patient does not move at all, lest the molten lead reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place over the eye of the patient cotton soaked in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the location of the fistula and heals it with wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	But if the fistula heals with what we have said regarding cautery and treatment, that is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	But if not, then it is necessary to perform trephining of the nose and reduce the fistula to its course through the nose according to what will come up in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cautery for cracks in the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures often occur in the lip, which are called 'hairs', especially in children's lips.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	But when you treat these fissures and the treatment does not help, then prepare a small cautery knife with this shape.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its hollow should be like that of a scalpel.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then quickly place it while hot into the actual fissures until the cautery reaches the bottom of them.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with wax, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the Method of Cauterizing a Fistula on the Face.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of a gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of teeth; then pus forms and bursts: afterwards it becomes hard, and pus continues to flow, and a fistula forms: if treatment is ineffective, then you must prepare a cautery according to its size that can fit into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert it while hot into the opening of the fistula and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches its bottom and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then dress it afterwards with what was mentioned about dressing until it heals.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If the pus is cut off and heals, that will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	But if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the rotted bone according to how it comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the Method of Cauterizing Softened Gums and Teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened due to moisture and the teeth are loose, and treatment with medicines does not help; then place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then prepare a cautery of the shape that will be described later so that you can place a cannula over the tooth; insert the heated cautery quickly into it and hold your hand briefly until the patient feels the heat of the fire having reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And raise your hand; then repeat the cautery as many times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill their mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour; then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth's movement is strengthened, and the gums are softened and tightened, thus drying out corrupted moisture.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing for tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When tooth pain is due to coldness, whether it's caused by cold itself or a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help: then cauterization is necessary in two ways: either using a cautery with butter or using a hot cautery.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is made by taking fresh butter and melting it in an iron spoon or bronze vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a piece of cotton, dip it into the melted butter, and apply it to the tip of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the cotton in boiling butter, quickly apply it to the painful tooth, and hold it until it cools. Repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If you wish, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth. Then put a hot iron on top of it until the heat reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Cauterization with fire is done using an air tube or an iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And it should have some thickness to prevent the heat from reaching the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take the cautery with fire, whose shape you will see, and apply it to that tooth. Hold your hand until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times; for the pain will be removed either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And when using that cautery, the patient should fill their mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	You can use whichever end you wish to cauterize, as much as possible. This is the shape of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing boils.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When boils are filled with phlegm and cold moistures, and do not yield to digestion by medicines, and require rapid digestion, then use a hollow cautery heated over fire, the shape of which is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It has two open ends, so that smoke can escape from one end. Place the heated cautery on the boil once or twice until it reaches the depth of the boil.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the boil is small, then place the cautery according to its size.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days and apply a poultice made with butter until what was burnt by the fire falls off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with toothache salve until it heals in the shape of a tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and shortness of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When excess moistures accumulate on the lung canal, especially when it is accompanied by coldness of temperament, then first evacuate the patient with dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at night on the root of the throat in a depressed place, and be careful not to reach the throat itself or the skin except for a small part.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck on the last vertebra. The cautery should be shaped like a nail according to the previous method.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing for lung ailments and coughing.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When coughing and lung ailments are caused by cold moistures, the patient does not have fever or phthisis, and the ailment is long-standing, then cauterize them with two cauteries on the fork of the neck in depressed, soft, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize [them] elsewhere in the middle of the chest between the two breasts with another cautery which is like the shape mentioned before.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to cauterize by pricking with a cautery, that is called 'Punctum', the shape of which was mentioned before in pricking ear pain, and let there be [made] thirty prickings up to nearly another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat him as mentioned before until he recovers.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore the cauterization is alleviated when you use instead of one cautery three cauteries at once.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	And the manner of cauterizing in the case of a twitching and dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the shoulder joint is dislocated due to moistures and it does not return to its proper place within an hour after being dislocated, until that becomes a habit for him, then it should be reduced first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the patient lie on his back or on his healthy side.
