¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Cutting, Piercing, and Bloodletting in Wounds, and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the First Chapter about every disease in which it is appropriate to use fire cautery and burning medicine, their indications, causes, instruments, and shapes of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I set forth there chapters from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same way, so that the seeker may find what he is looking for.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, O sons, it is necessary that you learn that what is in this chapter about cautery is even more terrifying than what is in the first chapter.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And therefore it is necessary that caution be even greater in this, since in the operation which is in this chapter, there often occurs evacuation with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of an exit, or cure of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of these trembling and fear arise, and many of them result in death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you not to fall into that about which there is hesitation, for sometimes people with various conditions come to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	Among them is he who becomes angry with his illness and finds death light: because of the vehemence of what he has found from his illness and the length of his wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with the illness, there is fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	Among them is he who offers his wealth and shares it with you, hoping for health, but his illness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, do not consent to him who comes to you from among them whose way is like this.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be greater than your greed and desire for gain.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him unless after certain knowledge which proves among you that he has achieved worthy success.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the care of all your patients prognosis and indication about that towards which health is suitably directed.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that there is for you assistance towards acquiring fame and glory, and remembrance and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with His understanding, and not take away from you guidance and inspiration: for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this chapter by dividing it into chapters according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from the neck to the feet: so that you may find easily what you seek from it and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	On the treatment of water which collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this illness often happens to children at birth or when the midwife tightly squeezes the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it also happens due to an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	I myself have not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and death hastened to all whom I saw with it. Therefore, it seemed to me necessary to leave the operation on that.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	I myself saw among them a boy whose head was filled with water and swelled every day until he could no longer sit up due to the size of his head. The fluid increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	This fluid either collects between the skin and bone or collects under the bone over the forehead.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	As for the operation on this [condition], if there is fluid between the skin and bone and the abscess is small, then you should make a single slit in the middle of the head's seam with a width of about two joints until the fluid flows out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the form of the operation.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If however the fluid has increased more and the abscess is larger, then make two incisions following this pattern.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	But if the fluid is under the bone and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head opened on all sides, and when you press it with your hand towards the interior, water appears and does not hide from you: then you should make three incisions in the middle of the head according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	After the incision, remove all the fluid.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the incisions with bandages and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then dress it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then remove the bandage and treat the wound with linens and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not leave the head bound unevenly.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	Feed the patient with dry food of little moisture until the member is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to observe where the size of the abscess and collection of water appear.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because sometimes it is more in the occiput, or forehead, or on the right or left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore, make your incision where you see the abscess and accumulation of water appear, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe that you do not cut the artery, lest there be a flow of blood and the patient dies from that flow along with the evacuation of humidity.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the Incision of Arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	If purulent matter occurs around the eyes or chest of someone, and it becomes chronic without being helped by medical treatment, then the ultimate remedy for that is the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to cut them, it is necessary that the patient uncover his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a coarse cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the patient tie his neck with any of his clothes.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And these places are located behind the ears and depressed; they are rarely concealed unless in certain individuals.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark both places with cauterization and cut each with a small, sharp instrument on either side until it reaches the bone, and let this be done along the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	If you wish, insert a small instrument beneath the artery and cut it upward with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood issues forth in a pulsating manner, which flows upwards rapidly and frequently into the inner parts.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear visibly, then it is necessary to measure from the ear the quantity of space equal to three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with cauterization and feel for it until you reach the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what ought to be emitted from the blood is about six ounces, although you may emit more or less than that.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this depends on the quantity which appears to you according to the strength of the patient and the fullness of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then observe the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If anything remains attached to the bone from the cutting, then cut that off so that a hot abscess does not occur; then tie the wound with bandages made of linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	And on extracting arterial vessels found in temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When an old headache or sharp catarrh occurs due to acrimonious humidities and heat in the temples' nerves, or old soda and similar things; and it is treated by medicinal methods of treatment without effect: then we have tried extraction of arterial vessels from the temples, or cauterization of them, as described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation for extracting them is: let the sick person shave the hair on the temples, and direct attention to the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	Indeed this [artery] becomes evident by its pulsation, and is rarely concealed unless in a few men or due to extreme cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is not evident to you, then let the sick person bind his head with any cloth he has; then rub the place with a coarse cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or warm the place with hot steam until its appearance becomes manifest.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the scalpel which I made earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then gently scrape off the skin with it until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert a hook into it and extract it upwards until you extract it from the skin, and remove it from all its surrounding tissues.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is slender: then envelop it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut off a piece from it according to how much its ends extend and contract, so that bleeding does not occur.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut or severed, blood will not flow upwards at all.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then express six drops of blood from it using the hook, up to three times.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large: then it is necessary to ligate it in two places with a strong double thread made of silk or horsehair, so that decay does not reach it before the wound is consolidated and bleeding occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut the superfluity which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that hour or another hour afterward.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a knife cautery until its ends are cut off and remains in the place of the operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	But this method is better unless the patient has a fever or is of hot temperament.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For cautery is among those things which help to dry moistures.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	So it is the better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the removal of the arteries, it is necessary that the place be filled with old cooked wax and powders properly made be put upon it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the dressing, treat it with dry medicines that promote flesh growth and with linen until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if during the operation blood flows from the artery, then quickly cut it with a cautery or fill the place with wax and press your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	But if none of these are present, then put your finger on the place until the blood coagulates.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And apply cold water to the place until the pain subsides and the dressing is applied properly.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for a lighter and easier removal of the artery, cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives, the sharpness of both knives being like an almadat.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	But they are much less sharp than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are as sharp as the two knives, both will become cold quickly and will not cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, since they have some thickness, the heat of the fire is retained in them and the flesh is cut quickly. Therefore this operation is better than any other, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between two cauterizing irons be as thick as a finger. After you mark two places with the hot iron, set them aside until they reach the bone, and strike the vein in both places so that it may stretch out what is between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For these cauteries do not completely harden.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of frequent and sharp pains in the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are frequent tears and their course is from the veins that are on the outside of the skull of the head, and no cure can be brought about by medicine with medicines; and you see the face of the patient beginning to redden, and he feels a creeping sensation in his forehead, like the crawling of ants, and his eyes are sunken and moist, so that even the lashes have become rotted away through moisture; and the eyelids are hot from the acuteness of the tears: then the ancients needed this operation for their cure, which they called 'operation with a knife'.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And first, you should order the patient to shave the hairs from his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions in the forehead equally spaced along its length. Each incision should be about two fingers long, and one should be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second a little further along towards the temple, and the third on the other side. Be careful not to cut into the arteries that are on both sides, and keep your hand away from the continuation of the two jaws. The space of each incision should be as wide as three joined fingers. Have ready some dry sponges or many pieces of cloth with which you can wipe away the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a probe with two sharp ends, whose shape is as follows:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	Starting from the incision on the temple side, go up to the second incision and strip off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions together with the pericranium that is over the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	And do likewise from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove this probe and insert into the first incision another instrument called the scalpel, sharp on one side and blunt on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape:
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And hold its sharp edge towards the flesh attached to the skin and its blunt edge towards the bone, and push it until it reaches the middle incision. Then cut with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except for those which are continuous with the incision up to where the skin appears.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do likewise from the middle incision to the other incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal amount of blood has flowed out, squeeze the places with pieces of dried blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in every incision a linen cloth from old cotton and put over them poultices soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And make sure no hot abscess forms.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	On the third day dissolve the suture and apply a lot of warm water rinse.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with balsam ointment and other remedies used for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On treating sharp pains and cataracts in the eyes from within the head.
Caput V.	Chapter Five.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When sharp, biting, persistent cataracts occur to someone: and you see their eyes wasted away, small, and the appearance of them weakened; and the eyelids ulcerated, and hairs falling out from them, and there is sharp pain in the depth of the head, causing injury, and coughing follows: then know that these accidents happen because those materials, and cataracts do not come unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for these is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is to order the patient to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly longer across its width, and begin cutting from the left temple to the right temple; let the incision be until it reaches the bone. And extend your hand away from the temples which move during mastication until when you expose the bone. Then dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the wound using a boiled old cloth or linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie it from above with wool. And moisten the wool with wine and oil so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you open it, and you see that the hot abscess has diminished, then you must scrape the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that promotes flesh growth: thus if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, and prepare an ointment from them, it should be applied to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On treating what falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter Six.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Every object that falls into the ear is of one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is liquid, such as water and vinegar and things like them; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When a stone falls into the ear, or some other substance that does not adhere and grow within it, expose the ear to the sunlight. If you see the stone, then pour a little violet oil or rosewater into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the removal of it [the stone], and cause sneezing with condiments, and hold a cloth against the nostrils upon approach of sneezing, after which you place pieces of linen or wool around the ear and pull the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For indeed many times does it exit with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not exit, then administer its removal with the Gestum, that is, with delicate tweezers; the shape of which is like this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore it exits with the Gestum, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its removal with a delicate bent hook of few turns.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not exit through that [the hook], then make a cannula of brass and insert its end into the opening of the ear far in, and seal what is around the cannula with softened wax mixed with oil so that there may be no way for wind except through the cannula: then extract it with strong suction of your breath.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For indeed many times does it exit with what we have mentioned.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not exit this way: then take a little from the helkalimbat or from dough, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught; and place it on the end of a rod after you have wrapped it with a cloth well placed. Then insert it gently into the opening of the ear after you have dried the ear.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not exit with all that we have mentioned, then hurry to cut before hot inflammation or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of cutting is such that the physician should first perform phlebotomy on the patient at the cephalic vein and remove blood according to his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, turn their ear towards the upper parts and find a small incision in the root of the ear at its depressed place. Make the incision crescent-shaped until you reach the stone, then remove it together with what is possible using your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then quickly stitch up the wound with care, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if there is a foreign body in the ear like a grain that grows and swells, then perform its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey you for exit, then take a thin, fine hook in this shape:
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And use it to cut off that kind of grain which falls into the ear. Do not do this when you think that the grain has already been moistened by the vapor of the ear until you put in many pieces. Then remove them with hooks or a fine pair of forceps, or with suction as we have said, for its removal will be facilitated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But concerning water that enters the ear, the patient should use sneezing first. Then fill the ear with some warm old oil and lie down on the side of the ear where there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out through that [means], it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not, then take many stones of the length and thickness of a finger, soften them with heat for a short time, and have the patient insert one of them into the opening of his ear. Then let him stand on one foot on that side and strike the inserted stone gently with another stone from outside.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not cease doing this with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out thus, that you may take one from a feather or from a reed and insert one end into the ear, and light the other end with fire until it burns greatly.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat this with another reed many times, until all the water comes out. And remove it with a cannula as has been described previously on the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in the removal of an animate creature that has entered it, if it is small-bodied, like a flea or similar, treat it as I have said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is large-bodied and apparent to the senses, then perform its removal with hooks and forceps. And this task is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the removal of a worm born in the ear, when you treat it with what has been said in division and in the treatise on distillation, but your treatment does not succeed: then it is necessary that you look at the ear towards the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something from the worms appears there, then remove it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula of this shape, narrow below and wide above. And insert its fine end into the ear according to how much the sick person can tolerate it, and then suck with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to come out, then seal around the cannula with wax as I have said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out with what has been said, then perform the distillations that the ancients have proven effective in killing worms, and you will find this in the treatise on distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring be such when you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow below with a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore, let the plunger that fits into the concave part of the cannula be made of well-crafted brass.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	If you wish, take a wand and wrap cotton around its tip in an appropriate wrapping. Then pour oil or juice or any of the medicines you wish into the cannula, with it placed in the ear. Next, insert the wand with the cotton onto it from above, and press it gently with your hand until the oil is pushed into the concavity of the ear, so that the patient feels its warmth inside. And whatever is dripped into the ear should be warmed a little with fire, and be careful that nothing very cold distills into it, for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of accidental perforation of the ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants are born from their mothers' wombs without being pierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has happened that some people have had blockage of the ear's passage due to injury or flesh grown within it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this blockage sometimes occurs deep inside the ear canal where it cannot be seen, and at other times it happens near the opening of the ear canal where it can be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, blockage that occurs deep inside the ear canal and cannot be seen is difficult to treat in most cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And with the one that can be seen, you should place the patient's ear in sunlight and look into it. If you see an apparent blockage, open it with a fine spatula, whose shape is as follows: its tip should have a small width, part of which is sharp; the rest of the spatula should have two smooth sides so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the blockage is due to flesh grown within the ear canal, then grasp it with a fine hook and cut it away with great ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the blockage is deep within the ear, then take a thin, gentle probe and heat it slightly with fire. Then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you find a blockage with what caused the patient's hearing difficulty, try to remove it gently; and be careful not to injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place a wick made from linen according to the size of the wound's opening into the ear, soaked in Egyptian ointment. Do this for several days until you are sure that the wound has healed properly.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a wick and soak it in rosewater, then dust it with powdered saffron, and use it as such.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	But if you see that the ear has begun to swell, then remove the wick and allow it to rest with another wick soaked in cerate made with rose oil until the swelling subsides. Then treat it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if bleeding occurs, then dip a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear. Then use the other treatments mentioned earlier in this treatise to stop the bleeding.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the treatment of swelling of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These swellings that occur on the eyelids can sometimes be moist and at other times dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, hold them with forceps or with a hook, and cut them away from their roots using scissors.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place powdered saffron on the area.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lens-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after cutting.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when some of their roots remain.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Chapter on the Treatment of Swelling of the Eyelids.
Caput IX.	Chapter Nine.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens that something resembling a grain in strength and hardness appears on the eyelids, and because of this it is called a swelling. It is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, the operation for these is: first consider whether it is a swelling that has appeared on the eyelid and moves towards all parts, and its consistency is soft.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Make an incision over it lengthwise.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then tear it out from every part with ease until it is completely removed.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if its removal cannot be accomplished without first making a small incision into the eyelid, then it causes harm to the sick person.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the incision is large: then gather it together with stitches and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and joins it together.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the swelling leans towards the inside of the ear on the inner surface, then turn back the eyelid and hang the swelling with a hook. Except for needing an incision, press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is elongated by the incision, this causes no harm.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then rinse the eye after the removal of the swelling with salt water and care for the area with something that promotes healing until the sick person is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	Chapter on the Treatment of Swelling of the Eyebrows.
Caput X.	Chapter Ten.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is fat that is produced in the skin of the upper eyelid. This happens most often to children and it weighs down their eyes. They suffer from catarrh in the mornings and cannot look at sunlight because tears flow towards them. Therefore, you see them always leaning on their faces and sleeping upon them. Their eyelids are moist under the eyebrows which have already become swollen due to inflammation. The prominence of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press the area with your fingers, you can feel it between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And its method of operation is that the sick person places their head on thy lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare upon it some thread, and make from that thread a circle according to the size that contains Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it upon it, and press with your fingers on all sides so that Axirnath may gather in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then make an incision with a scalpel in the midst of that moisture along its width and not deeper than the incisions made for bloodletting.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Otherwise you must cut the skin all the way until you reach Axirnath, for in many cases Axirnath proceeds from the incision like a piece of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then remove it with a cloth that you have moistened between your fingers on the outside and roll your hand to the right and left until it disperses. And beware not to push further into the incision lest you reach the eye with the scalpel and harm it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if Axirnath does not appear at first in the incision, you should proceed gently until Axirnath comes forth.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then remove it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak some cloths in vinegar and water and place them on the location, and secure them with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some people who grind salt and apply it to the hollow of the incision so that what remains of that moisture may be dissolved.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if a hot abscess forms there, then treat it with soothing poultices until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the ways of treating styes of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes inflamed so that it droops as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs are born in the eyelids besides their natural course and grow long, they cause harm to the eye and bring about ways of illness, such as constant tears, inflammation of the eyelids, and cloudiness until it causes destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And styes of the eye are treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as is mentioned in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or styes are treated by incising and sewing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by means of cups, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must put the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns easily, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it does not turn easily: insert a needle into the eyelid where there is thread from below, and make the needle penetrate upwards with the thread close to the hairs themselves, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid where the hairs are growing; then pull the thread upward with the eyelid and turn it back with your finger.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find the added hairs on the inside of the eyelid using tweezers, cutting from the larger tear duct to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread and place a small wisp of cotton or cloth under the eyelid; then mark the eyelid with a cautery in the shape of a fig leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, the figure should be made according to the size and height of the eyelid, because these vary greatly among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For those who need to have a large amount cut from their eyelid, it should be measured according to the size that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with a fine spatula, find the space between the two lines that you have marked, and begin from the larger tear duct to the smaller one. The incision should be one near the natural hairs, like the thickness of a reed.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then strip off all of it.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together the two lips with a suture using needle and fine wool thread. Remove any blood, and make what is excess of the threads adhere to both eyebrows. If you wish, use some sticky substances; if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads in place for three or four days before caring for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without a suture and treat it with something that dries and tightens it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will swell after cauterization of the wound and its closure, but in the future it will be better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment was taught by the ancients called Atashmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is carefulness about the sick person involved, and it comes from good practice, not fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	There is also another method in Atashmir: which is to mark on the eyelid the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks according to this following shape. Then cut off what is excess with small forceps according to this shape, making the cuts equal in depth.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook and make it equal, then take a needle with thread on it and insert it into the middle of the figure. Then insert another thread near the larger tear duct and a second one near the smaller tear duct. Then bring together the threads between your fingers evenly.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation and raise the skin over which the tumor is marked, as I have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then approximate the two lips of the wound with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if an abscess should form at your incision or wound, cauterize it with caustic substances and similar ointments that have a soothing effect.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelids also become inverted, such that their hairs turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we have said about incision in this case, but the suture for both is more artful.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Chapter on treating hemorrhoids with ligatures.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is necessary that you turn back the eyelid and cut open the wound that is on the inside, as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then skillfully make two ligatures or thin pieces of wood, whose length is equal to the length of the eyelid and width less than the width of a grain. And you have already cut at both ends where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then carefully bring both together over that which protrudes from the eyelid of the eye and tie them tightly on both sides with a strong ligature, and leave it in place for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin tied too tightly will die, turn black, and decay until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it takes too long, then cut it with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it becomes firm, raise the eyelid and the hairs will no longer irritate it.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of the two ligatures which you should make according to this figure and measurement in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Here follows the method for removing piercing hairs from the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is as follows: take a fine needle and insert into it a thread of silk, soft and thin.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then bind the ends with a very fine knot, one on each end; let the length of the threads be the span of one hand.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then place under it another fine thread and bind its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the patient lay his head in your lap, facing the sun so that the operation may be clear to see, for it is a delicate or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with its thread into the root of the eyelid and push it through quickly until you draw out a natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up along with the thread; and insert into the thread that one hair only, or two, or three, but not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand gently until the thread with its hair comes out from under the eyelid along with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread comes out without the hair, then pull it downwards along with the other thread you inserted into it until the first thread emerges from above. Then when you see the eye clearly, pull both threads together and remove them; close the eye and let it remain closed for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	But if the hair is short, then either join it with a longer natural hair and remove them both together, or leave it alone until it grows longer, and then remove it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Here follows the treatment of inflammation that occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this inflammation occurs to the eye, it is called "lepra.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this leprosy is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental leprosy occurs from the solidification of a wound, or from an incision, cautery, or similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	The method of treatment for this condition is to locate the solidification and separate its lips, then place a linen wick between them and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	But do not use in its treatment things that dry and constrict, for if you do so, the leprosy will return worse than before. Instead, use things that soften, such as fennel-greek; shave with water in which althea has been cooked and linseed has been steeped; and apply a poultice made from diacilicon ointment, mixed with some oil, and wrap it around a linen cloth for the cure.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasure in healing is to strive by all means to prevent consolidation, according to the original form that it had at first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And indeed this operation we have spoken of is only a certain correction of leprosy, so that the form of the place does not return entirely as it was before.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Chapter: On the treatment of leprosy that occurs on the lower eyelid and causes wrinkling or contraction upwards towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This leprosy that occurs below is truly called "leprosy.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it can be either natural or accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	Accidental leprosy occurs from a wound, fissure, cautery, or similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	The method of treatment for this condition is to take a needle with double thread and stain it with flesh color, then make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right until the thread emerges at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut it with a broad-bladed knife.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the shape of the eyelid returns as it should be, that is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not [the eyelid returns to its proper shape], take a probe and place it in the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it: and make two incisions on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two incisions meet at two angles, until they converge and form an angle: so that when they are joined together, this figure is formed, which is the shape of the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that piece of flesh, which is the acute side facing downwards, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts together: whether with a thread made of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said about softening medicines and linens until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if a hematoma occurs from the incision and suture or cauterization: then it is necessary to make an additional planar incision beneath the hairs of the eyelid, just as before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with linen, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And in summary, concerning the treatment of hematoma whether it is above or below [the eye], the operation should be performed according to how the hematoma is prepared.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it [the hematoma] has many variations in shape: and a skilled artisan prepares his ingenuity with whatever means are possible for him until he restores the shape to its natural form or near it, and the patient himself, according to what is fitting for him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	¶ Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this condition occurs in many people, such that the upper eyelid becomes adherent to the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, it is necessary to insert the end of a probe under the eyelid and raise it upwards or extend it with a hook: then incise the adhesion with a spatha (a blunt instrument), which should not have too sharp an edge, but rather be somewhat blunt: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatha does not harm the eye with its sharpness. Make your incision as if you are scraping away the adhesion easily, until the eyelid returns to its natural shape and the adhesion heals completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour saltwater into the eye and rinse it with water or distill a solution of sulfur dissolved in water onto it.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen thread and place over the eye a wick soaked in egg white. After three days, use sulfur and salves until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Chapter on Cutting the Nail and Excising a Fleshy Growth of the Tear Duct
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail has two forms.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Either it is nervine: and it resembles a piece of hard, thin horn.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 Or it is not nervine, resembling frozen white moisture. When touched by iron or when tried to be grasped with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not stick in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin unless from the larger tear duct, gradually advancing until it covers the sight and blocks light and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method of operation for cutting it is that the patient should lay their head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open the patient's eyes and raise the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Next, grasp the nail with a hook of moderate size and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a hair from a horse, ox, or cow - let the thread be strong and double the end of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail. Then pierce it with the needle and tie the nail with the thread, extending it upwards. Then scrape the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were cutting it with the hair until its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remaining part at the root of the tear duct with a fine scalpel or small forceps. Ensure not to damage the natural tissue of the tear duct so that there is no continuous flow of tears due to the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail extends only with a hook alone; or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it gently with a scalpel, which has this shape:
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware that the scalpel does not touch the corneal tunic and cause a break or perforation of the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, sprinkle some crushed salt or powdered verdigris into the eye and leave it overnight.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the nail is not nerve-like and you cannot insert a needle into it nor can it hold a hook, then this type of nail is cured many times with medications as I have explained in its division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	But if you wish to cut it, then open the sick eye and take a fine, gentle scalpel with blunted sharpness in this shape:
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And carefully shave off the nail from above with finesse.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	But if you see that it becomes rarefied and broken, and the razor presses upon it, then distill from your hour into the eye a powder made of verdigris or red ocher or ground salt. Then bandage the eye overnight.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat this procedure until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is a warm abscess in the eye, then leave it alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure on it with care until it is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	If the prominence of the lacrimal gland causes great harm to the eye, it should be suspended with a hook and a portion of it cut away; but do not make the last cut too deep, lest the flow of tears be obstructed.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then instill into the tear duct red sulphur or powder made from cinabar until it is healed.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Regarding the incision of the pterygium and flesh born in the eye
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A red flesh sometimes grows in the eyes of certain people, spreading until it covers the pupil or approaches and presses upon the eyelids, even causing them to turn outward, resembling a cock's-comb.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation for this is that the patient should place their head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open the eye and grasp that flesh entirely with suitable hooks; hold it with one forceps or your hand.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut into the flesh first, until the entire length of it is reached with the scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful not to injure the eye during the operation. The cut should be made either with a scalpel or with the spatula previously mentioned for nail cutting, or with small forceps, according to how convenient it is after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When the incision is complete and the entire pterygium has been removed, then fill the eye with powdered salt or instill red sulphur powder into it, along with other corrosive medications. Then place a white-hot cautery on the outside of the eye to prevent inflammation.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.
