But if some part of the pterygium remains and there is a risk of hot inflammation and you fear an abscess, then leave the eye alone and treat it with something that cools the inflammation.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure on it until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And similarly do with the added flesh that occurs in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that you perform surgery on every weak eye with the aid of a knife, both by way of nature and accident; and do not undertake any of these operations until you have seen that that member can endure them.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	Chapter On The Extraction Of A Foreign Body From The Eye
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebel are red veins that grow over the eye and hinder its vision, and weaken the eye with prolonged duration.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore, it is necessary for you first to observe whether the eye with sebel is strong and has no other sickness besides sebel; then extract the sebel from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And tell the patient to put their head on your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one hook or two according to your discretion; and let the hook be of fine double curvature, like this shape, or let there be two hooks graduated on one body, like this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then gently grasp those veins with fine forceps and remove the blood little by little until you see that those veins have been removed from the eye and are resolved; and be careful not to injure the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation take place at midday before the sun, and be very steady in your operation so that you do not touch anything but those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then apply collyrium either green or red to the eye so that its sharpness may corrode any remainingtrace of sebel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if you are not able to extract all of it at once, then apply a plaster to the eye with something that soothes the pain; and let him rest for several days until the pain subsides and hot inflammation is secured. Then repeat the procedure in the same manner until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	¶ On the reduction of a dislocated nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The doctors call it "Arissati," which they treat either with a cautery or by burning it with an acrid medicine, depending on what has been told about its condition.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it is not cured, then there is no hope for it except to open a window above the abscess at its origin and remove all the moisture and pus that is within it until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is exposed and you see corruption or blackness on it, then scrape it with an instrument whose shape is like this:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called "Asperi's head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Make it from hard iron and let its head be round like a hazelnut, which is pierced with the point of a file or with a fine punch; then place it on the site of the bone corruption.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then rotate it between your fingers and press your hand lightly until you know that the corruption has been scraped away; do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the site with drying astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If the site solidifies and flesh grows there, and the flow of pus is cut off, and it remains for forty days without renewing or forming an abscess, and no complication arises, then know that it has been cured.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no hope except to reduce the fistula to the nostril according to this shape:
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is so that you expose the bone from below with iron or an acrid medicine; and when the bone is exposed, then take a probe of this shape, its iron tip being triangular, and its wood tapering to a point like this.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it on the bone itself; let it be near the tear duct; and extend your hand slightly away from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then rotate your hand with the probe until it pierces the bone and the patient feels it; by this you will know that air is escaping from it when they place their hand over their nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore, then restore the site with drying astringent medicines, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	Thus when flesh grows and the site becomes hardened, then the material that was flowing outward will return to the nose; therefore this is easier for the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	Chapter on Reducing Protrusion of the Eye
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes completely and there is no harm to sight or diminution, then it is necessary for you to loosen the patient; afterwards bleed them; then apply cupping glasses to the neck without incision but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place over the eye a plaster made from acacia, and aloe, and frankincense, and tragacanth gum.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye above the plaster with many small wicks.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of the wicks is this: take soft cloths, many of them, and fold each one over four times; make many of these; then place them one on top of another according to the quantity that the eye needs; then bind them with a hard cloth using strong binding.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat cupping with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cups and leave the eye bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the binding becomes soft again, then it is necessary to bind it tightly; then remove the binding after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see that the eye has returned to its normal position, then that is good; but if not, then repeat the plaster and wicks, and binding, and cupping until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Chapter on Incising the Upper Eyelid
Caput XXI.	Quando non est uisus profectus in Oculo ex praecedenti medicina, erit necessarium ut incidas uae tunicam: et hoc facies sic.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When there is a disruption in the upper eyelid, then the protruding swelling will come out beyond the eyelids like a grain of barley and disfigure the face; if you wish to incise it, then perform the operation as follows: insert a needle into the root of the swelling from below towards the top.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle with a doubled thread on the lacrimal side and pass it through; leave the first needle in its original position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the location of the doubled thread and tie the eyelid around the needle with it; then pull it tight.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, place a piece of wool soaked in egg white over the eye; leave him until the thread falls out with the swelling.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with ointment that will strengthen it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the swelling is tied from all sides with a bandage made of cloth until the eye becomes very protuberant.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a fine trocar that reaches deep into the eye; let the aqueous humor flow out and allow the eye to sink down immediately; then bind it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	And concerning the treatment of haemorrhoids:
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This condition called haemorrhoids is nothing but a collection of watery fluid in the eye, and it is not actually blood.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	The method for treating this condition is to have the patient sit on a prepared or upright chair.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take hold of his head with both your hands and move him until you see the fluid reaching below his eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then catch it quickly so that it does not flow down and blur the vision; if the patient can see clearly again, know that it was water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the fluid does not flow down as described above, then have the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine trocar and pierce the conjunctiva slightly above the limbus of the cornea until the fluid comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When the fluid comes out, then instill warm water mixed with honey into the eye: or warm water in which you have already boiled mallow and honey: thereafter treat it with the remaining treatment until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that descends into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXII
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already discussed the types of water and which is suitable for piercing, now take that same one according to its suitability.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then have the patient sit between your hands facing a square opening towards the light, near the sun: and tie their healthy eye, and bind them tightly: then with your right hand lift the eyelid of their left eye if it is the eye with the water, or with your left hand if it is the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take an eyelid retractor in your right hand if it's the left eye, or in your left hand if it's the right eye.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the eyelid retractor near the limbus towards the thickness of the radius where the smaller lacrimal duct appears: then push the eyelid retractor with force and you rotate your hand with it until it penetrates into the eyeball and you feel that the eyelid retractor has reached an empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the path of the eyelid retractor into the depth be equal to the space from the pupil to the end of the blackness which is the limbus of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it in the pupil itself through the clearness of the corneal tunic.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the eyelid retractor until it reaches the location where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press down on it repeatedly, one after the other.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If water descends immediately, then the patient will see the object upon which they opened their sight immediately, and the eyelid retractor will be in their eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water descends, then pour it out again, except for the eyelid retractor.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When the fluid is drawn up and does not ascend, then remove the eyelid retractor gently; and you should slowly roll your hand back.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve some clear salt of the stone in water and wash the eye with it inside.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place a wick or wool soaked in rose oil outside the eye, and press gently on the eyelid; then bind it with a healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those of our time, place powdered incense mixed with egg white upon him.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the eyelid retractor does not obey you when entering the eye due to its hardness, because it is made from human bone and has a very hard eye, then you should take spatumile, also known as Albied, which has this form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore insert it only into the joint with it, and do not put your hand further into the opening; otherwise you will be unable to reach the delicate eyelid retractor.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the eyelid retractor as we have described.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your operation, prepare for the patient a well-made bed where they can sleep on their back in a dark room; prevent them from all movements and coughing, and give them food that soothes their nature. They should not move their head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage remain in place according to its arrangement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then remove it on the third day in that dark room, and test his sight; make him see objects.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reapply the bandage until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not appropriate for him to do this at the time of treatment or immediately after an incision; rather, it should be done by someone else because water ascends rapidly due to intense staring.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however a hot swelling occurs, then it is necessary to open the eye before the seventh day, and correct it with something that subdues the swelling until it is subdued; then without its sight, place on his face an eyepatch which regulates his vision for several days while he remains in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then gradually leave the house and return to one's own home.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that during the zealot period, the disciple is not excused from seeing sometimes; then he may dare to perform an operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed, one of those from Al-Rayy has come to us who said that a cistern was pierced there through which water flows.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this, nor have I read it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that this is something new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of creatures that come from the cistern, so that he who does not know may stand upon them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made properly out of bronze and their ends be triangularly pointed with the same fineness, and let one end be sharp.
Formae magda.	Forms of the cistern.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Prologue: On the Treatment of a Flesh Growth in the Nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes various kinds of flesh are born in the nose from which there is something resembling a many-legged scorpion, and from it there is fleshy, bony, dark-colored flesh; and from it there is also soft flesh that is not dark-colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, in the case of that which is soft and not deceitful or cancerous among these kinds of flesh, it is necessary for you to make the patient sit between your hands facing the sun, open his nostrils, insert a hook into those fleshy growths, then pull them outwards, and cut off with a sharp and fine spatula from one side what you have grasped until you know that all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if there remains something of it which cannot be cut off: then shave that with one of the subtle instruments with ease until nothing remains.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood dominates over you, or a hot abscess occurs: then apply to it what is necessary according to what is appropriate. Or if it is one of the malicious kinds of swellings, then hurry to cauterize him until the blood is cut off and all the flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then after the incision, throw vinegar and water or wine into the nostril.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the nostril opens up and moisture proceeds from it to the palate, then know that he is now healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that there is flesh born in the upper bones of the nostril which was not reached by the instrument with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore it is necessary that you insert a thread of linen with some thickness and many knots tied in it, placing between each knot the amount of a finger or less. Then let the patient introduce one end of the thread into his nostril with a probe or whatever he can manage afterwards making it resemble an awl, and draw out his scent until it reaches the throat and emerges above his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And indeed many children do this like thing in schools: and it is easy for him who wishes to do so.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two ends of the thread, one that emerges above the nostril and another that remains inside the nostril.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then bring a cutter for cutting flesh with knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is already bound with knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the thread and insert into the nostril, after wiping away blood, a wick which you have dipped in Egyptian ointment. Do this for three days or more until the ointment has eaten away all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place at the end of it into the nostril a tube of lead for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however treatment that dries is needed, use that one.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For making a head-purge vessel for distilling oils and other medications into the nostril, make it of silver or bronze, resembling a small lantern with an opening like a shell, having a similar passage.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed tube, such as a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the vessel for making a head-purge should be full and open at the bottom with a handle at its end with which to hold it when heating oil or other fluids in it.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Prologue: On the treatment of nasal bleeding
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	The nosebleed often originates at the tip of the nose and grows larger and increases with days until it becomes unsightly.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of this, it is necessary to cut off its beginning as soon as it appears and erase all of it entirely.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then apply either a cautery or a burning medicine to the place where it was, so that it stays in its location.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If the cutting of it is delayed until it becomes large, then consider if it is stony hard, dark in color, and insensitive. Do not touch it with iron, because it is a cancerous abscess.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen that those who cut into such an abscess suffer great harm from it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	But if the abscess is soft to touch, not dark in color, and you see that it can be cut into entirely, then evacuate the patient and cut into it without fear or worry. Treat the place with something that dries and contracts until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when there is a break in the continuity of one of these cartilages, it does not benefit much unless in certain people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, whenever something happens to someone from that area, you should consider if it is a fresh wound with its own blood. Then approximate the edges of the wound with suturing, and then treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	But if the lips of the discontinuity are already separated and each part has healed separately, then it is necessary to excise all the skin that appears until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then approximate the two lips with sutures and tighten them. Powder over the blood some dragon's blood powder and ground frankincense. Place on top a piece of plaster called diafinicon and another consolidated plaster, and leave it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then remove the dressing after two or three days, change the medicine, and leave it alone until the stitches fall out by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suturing is as follows: approximate the discontinuity either with needles, as we have described for abdominal closure, or with thread, as I have shown you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the removal of nodules from the lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people often have hard nodules like grains of wheat on the inside of their lips. Some are smaller and some larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, turn the lip over and make an incision over each node. Suspend it with a hook and cut into it on all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the incision with ground zinc oxide until the bleeding stops.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then it is bound with vinegar and the wound is treated with it, in which there is astringency, until the wounds are healed.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Concerning the incision of flesh born upon the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Flesh often grows on the gum which the ancients call abuluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore you should suspend it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing blood or pus to flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then apply ground zinc oxide powder or other drying astringent powders to the wound.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	But if that flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut it again and cauterize it; for it will not return after being cauterized.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Concerning the extraction of teeth with iron instruments
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes teeth are surrounded by rough and foul layers on their inner and outer surfaces, and between the gums, becoming blackened, yellowish, or greenish, until corruption reaches the gum and the teeth become fetid.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore make the patient sit between your hands and place their head in your lap. Grind away with a file any layer or deposit on the teeth that appears like sand until nothing remains of it, and do likewise for blackness, greenness, yellowishness, and other such impurities until the teeth are cleaned.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If what is being removed at the beginning of the extraction is good, that is fine. But if not, then repeat the extraction on another day, second and third times, until finally you achieve your goal.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that teeth require files of various shapes and forms according to how they are prepared for your operation. The file used to grind the lower part of a tooth is different from the one used between teeth due to their varied shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And have these forms of files ready at hand for you to see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Concerning the Extraction of Toothache.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You should strive to remove a tooth from its pain with all your skill, and be slow in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is nothing that can replace it once it is extracted, since it is a most noble substance. Therefore, until there is no excuse for extracting it, then it becomes necessary to extract the tooth when the patient is compelled to do so, in order that it may be made firm and certain in your hands.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For pain often deceives the patient, making him believe that it is in a sound tooth and causing him to extract it. But then the pain does not cease until the diseased tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We ourselves have seen this in the practice of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	Therefore, when you have assured yourself of the painful tooth itself, then it is necessary that you make an incision around the tooth with a scalpel in which there is some virtue, so that the gum may be loosened on all sides. Then move the tooth gently with your fingers or with fine forceps little by little until you feel it give way.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps with good position on the tooth and put the patient's head between your knees. When you have held it firmly so that it does not move, then pull out the tooth in a straight line so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it underneath the tooth on all sides with ease and try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or decayed, then it is necessary to fill that hole with cloth and tie it with a fine thread so that it may not break during your constriction of it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you should make an incision around the gum on all sides very carefully and thoroughly.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so that you do not break it off, lest a part of it remain and return upon the patient with greater pain than before.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And take care not to do what ignorant bloodletters often do in their haste and rashness when removing it beyond what we have instructed.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For oftentimes they cause great diseases to happen upon men, which are more difficult to cure, and all the roots of it remain, or some of them; or they draw it out with certain bones of the jaw, as we have often witnessed.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then let it be cauterized after its removal with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	But if bleeding occurs from the site (which often happens), then crush some incense and fill the place with it; and if you do not have incense, cauterize the spot.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forceps used to move a tooth should be fine-pointed with long tips and short handles, thick so that they do not close together when pressed against the tooth. They should resemble thick handles until when you squeeze them together they do not pinch or double over. The tips should be short and made of well-tempered iron or bronze, straight-edged, with teeth on their ends which fit into each other and grip tightly.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the tips are shaped like a bird's beak called a stork's beak, and these have a strong gripping power.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	[About] The Removal of Teeth and the Extraction of Broken Jaw Bones
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When a tooth remains to be removed which has broken off, then it is necessary to place cataplasm of butter upon the spot for one or two days until the place becomes softened. Then introduce an elevator or forceps whose tips resemble the shape of a bird's mouth called a stork's beak.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the shape of the forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their tips should be made like an awl inside: or like an alkibibis.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If the patient does not yield to you at the exit with these forceps, then it is necessary for you to make incisions over the root and strip all the flesh, and insert the instrument called "small lever," whose shape is as follows.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let its extremity be short, thick for a moment: and let it not be hollow, so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root emerges through this (instrument), it is good; and if not, help must be given with other instruments whose shapes are as follows.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first is triangular at its tip, with some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	Shape of the second: triangular tip, thin.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	And help is also given with this instrument having two branches, whose shape is as follows.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools that preceded it in the treatment of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	And also help is given with this instrument which resembles a large hook, of this shape, having a twisted triangular tip with some thickness so that it does not break; and let it not be hollow.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for teeth; and similarly the rest of the instruments are not numbered, and a skilled craftsman, subtle in his art finds an instrument himself according to what operation and conditions require.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because there are conditions to which the ancients did not mention an instrument because of the diversity of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if the bone breaks from the jawbone or other bones of the face, or becomes putrid, then examine it at its place with whatever is suitable for it among the instruments and forceps that I mentioned for extracting roots, and help with splints whose shape is as follows.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be some thickness gradually tapering in it so that it may bind or hold the bone and prevent it from escaping or moving until the bone comes out; and restore the place with suitable medicines for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a small decay in the bone, then scrape off the decay itself and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the treatment of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth are prominent beyond their natural course, it causes an unpleasant appearance, especially when this happens in women and young girls, namely those who are sold [i.e., married].
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore, one must consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth is born behind another and cannot be placed or its prominence cannot be corrected by trimming it, then extract it. And if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument of which this is the shape.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It resembles a small beak and is made of iron, very sharp at the tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And your cutting should take place over many days, on account of the hardness of the tooth and to avoid disturbing any other teeth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is prominently exposed to trimming, then trim it with a file made of iron whose shape is like this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of iron, and its handle full of many small points like the file used for making needles. With this file, the tooth is slowly trimmed over many days with ease so that it does not move or fall out. Then polish it gently, and finally scrape it smooth with some razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	But if there is a tooth from which a piece breaks off and hurts the tongue, then you should file it down until its sharp edge is removed and made smooth, so that it no longer hurts the tongue or interferes with speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On holding teeth in place with gold threads.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth are shaken and moved by blows or accidents and the patient cannot bite firmly without them falling out, even after treating them with medicinal astringents, then it is necessary to hold them in place using gold thread because silver turns green and decays over time.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And the thread should be of medium thickness, neither too thin nor too thick, according to the space between the teeth it must fit into.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	The method of binding is as follows: take the thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth. Then tie it with both ends between the loose tooth or teeth until you reach a healthy tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the tying until you reach the side where you began. Tie with care and wisdom so that it does not slip at all; your tying should be around the roots of the teeth so that it does not come loose.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excess ends of the thread with forceps and join them together. Bend them towards each other and hide them between the healthy tooth and the loose one so that they do not harm the tongue. Then leave it tied tightly like this until healing occurs.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it loosens or breaks, tie them again with another thread and they will remain stable like that for the entire duration of treatment.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of the teeth and the figure of binding two healthy teeth with two loose ones, as you can see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	Sometimes it happens that one or two teeth return to their original places after falling out completely. If they are held in place as we have described and remain there, this is only possible with the skill of a knowledgeable and experienced artisan.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	Sometimes a piece of bone from the jawbone is prepared and shaped like a tooth. It is then placed in the gap where the tooth was lost and held in place with thread as described earlier. This will remain and serve as a long-term solution.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On Incision of the Ligament Under the Tongue That Hinders Speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament under the tongue is natural, with which man is born, or it is accidental, due to an injury that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation on it is thus: Open the mouth of the sick person in your lap and lift his tongue. Then cut this nerve ligament across its width until the tongue is released from its restraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	But if there is something hard and knotty present, and it is due to the healing of a wound, then use a hook to throw into it and find it across its width until you cut the ligament and release the knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And beware lest there be a deep cut in the flesh and you cut an artery there, so that bleeding occurs.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then let it be sewn up at the site of the incision with rosewater, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a linen bandage which the patient should hold in place every night so that it does not heal again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if bleeding occurs, then put on the site of the cut a poultice made of cooked mustard.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if blood overcomes you, then cauterize the site with a slow-burning cautery suitable for that purpose. Then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the Extraction of a Cyst That Forms Under the Tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes under the tongue there appears a swelling resembling a small frog, which hinders the tongue from its natural movement, and perhaps becomes so large that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation on it is thus: Open the mouth of the sick person towards the sun and observe the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If you see it is dark colored or black, hard, and without sensation for the patient, then do not touch it because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	But if it is inclined towards whiteness with moisture present, then throw a hook into it and cut it with a sharp scalpel and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	But if blood overcomes you during your operation, then place upon it ground ginger until the bleeding ceases; then return to your task until you remove it with its entirety.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then cauterize it with vinegar and salt; and treat it with other appropriate treatment until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the Treatment of Abscesses of the Two Mandibles
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes swellings occur between the throat and the glands, that is, the glands which resemble almonds, which occur externally; these are called the two tonsils. When you treat them with what we have said concerning division, but they do not heal, then consider.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If therefore there is a hard abscess of dark color with little sensation, do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of red color and its root is thick, then do not touch it even with iron, fearing bleeding, but leave it until it ripens.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you will pierce it or it will burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	But if it is of white color, round, and its root is thin, then it must be cut open.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is as follows: before beginning your task, consider whether the abscess has become completely quiet and cold or has decreased somewhat. Then make the patient sit facing the sun, with his head in your lap, open his mouth, and have an assistant take hold of his tongue from below with an instrument shaped like this.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It should be made of silver or bronze, thin like a scalpel.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press the tongue with it and the abscess is revealed to you, then take a hook and insert it into the tonsil, and draw it out towards the outside as much as possible without tearing any of its membranes.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it open with an instrument shaped like this which follows:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles forceps; however, its ends are curved so that the opening of each is directly opposite the other at an acute angle. Therefore, ensure it is made from polished iron or gold-plated.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	But if this instrument is not available, then cut it open with a scalpel shaped like this:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let it be sharp on one side and blunt on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after cutting one tonsil, cut the other according to the same manner of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, let the patient gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if bleeding occurs, let him gargle with water in which pomegranate rinds have been boiled, or with myrtle leaves and similar astringent substances, until the bleeding stops; then treat it until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes other swellings appear in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore cut those likewise according to what I have said regarding the equal cutting of both tonsils.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I myself once treated a woman for an abscess that had formed in her throat and was drawing towards the windpipe, causing difficulty in breathing and making it almost impossible for her to swallow water. She could barely speak and was close to death, so that if left untreated she would have died within one or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had grown so much that it had sent forth two branches which had emerged through both nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	Therefore I hastened quickly and inserted a hook into one of them.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a large portion emerged from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off where it could be grasped through the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did to her what had protruded from the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed her tongue down. After that, I inserted a hook into the abscess itself, cut off part of it, and only a little blood flowed from it. Thus the woman's throat was cleared, and she immediately began to drink water and then took some food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not cease cutting away at that abscess many times over a long period of time. And the abscess kept growing back in place of what was being cut off, until it became extremely prolonged and grew with her.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I then applied an ipecacuanha ointment and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	And so it ceased to grow worse. Then I departed from her, not knowing what God would do with her afterwards.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the Incision of an Abscess on the Throat.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When phlegm descends to the throat and an abscess forms, if it is long, then it is called a "perpendicular"; but if it is thick and rounded at its lower part, then it is called a "grape".
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When treated with the method described earlier and no improvement is seen, and you observe that the abscess has become hot and thin, then it must be cut.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And if the one that is joined to it is round and has no length, and is bloody or dark colored or black, and has no sensation, then avoid cutting into it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is danger in harming the healthy part.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it as I described earlier in terms of its whiteness and length, make the patient sit facing the sun. Then press down her tongue with an instrument about which there is mention elsewhere. Insert a hook into the uvula and pull it downward. Cut it open using one of the two instruments mentioned for cutting two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you should not cut anything beyond what exceeds its natural limit without adding to it.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut more than that, you will injure the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use what we have described regarding the incision of two tonsils: and treat it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the patient is frightened by the incision, then you must use your ingenuity in cauterizing it without fear and dread.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterization is not otherwise than with sharp water: and it is, that you place the head of the patient upon your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take some of the water that I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and dip into it an un-extinguished ember, and place it not thickly nor thinly, and fill with it the hollow of this instrument, which has this shape.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let its end where the medicine is placed be concave like the concavity of a spoon's bowl.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine upon his throat: and let the patient lie on his side so that the salt water may flow out of his mouth from the internal medicine, so that nothing may fall down into his throat and harm him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you put it on his throat for the first time in the amount of half an hour until you see that it has turned black and the burning sensation of the medicine has subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take cotton and wrap it around the end of the spoon, and pour the medicine over it, and insert the spoon with the cotton into the cannula from above until the cotton adheres to his throat.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this repeatedly until you achieve what you desire regarding the cauterization of the throat.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then leave it; for it dries up and falls off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	But if you need to repeat the medicine, repeat it; and after cauterization, wipe around the throat with cotton soaked in butter, and cleanse with it what is around it from the medicine; and rinse with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with poultices, and internally with gargarisms, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Therefore, this method of treatment is more salutary after incision and further from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the throat is also cured with something that is gentler than cautery and incision; it is cured with fumigation, according to this method.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take rue, and hyssop, and oregano, and sage, and chamomile, and abrotane, and similar herbs; and mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and submerge them in vinegar, and let them boil; and the pot should be properly luted with clay: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which an concave instrument is placed in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or brass; and the extremity with the pomegranate shape should be inserted into the sick person's mouth until the vapor reaches the throat through the tube, until the throat becomes very dark.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this many times until it dries out.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an abscess formation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For usually it adds to an abscess; and you should not do this unless it is applied when the abscess is about to burst.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if you do not have this instrument, then take a reed and attach the skin of an egg at its end so that it does not burn the sick person's mouth; because the egg skin prevents the vapor from burning the mouth; and this is also good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the Extraction of Thorns and Bones from the Throat
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times a bone or fish spine becomes stuck in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore you must extract what is visible above it by pressing the tongue with an instrument towards the sun, and then it will be clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And whatever does not appear to you and is concealed in the throat must be done by vomiting before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the attached matter will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or let the sick person swallow a piece of radish root, or lettuce root, or swallow a dry piece of bread; or take a piece of dried sea sponge and tie it on a thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it reaches the place where the spine or bone is, and is extracted, then it will come out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If however it does not come out with what we have said, then use an instrument made of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a small rod for a moment, and at its end let there be a curvature which he introduces into his throat easily; and it itself should have its head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him be careful not to touch his epiglottis so that he does not cough, and with it he should press the bone or spine, or the doctor introduces it by hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But it is better for the sick person to introduce it himself because of his knowledge of where the attached matter is located, and he should press downwards or draw his hand upwards with the instrument, all of this according to the amount that is prepared for him until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of Bloodsuckers.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is treated with what I said regarding its division for treatment with medicines, and it does not attach itself, then examine the throat of the sick person before the sun or after pressing his tongue with the instrument that I have told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the leech, extract it with a small hook or with delicate tweezers skillfully.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if this is not possible with them, then take a hollow cannula and introduce it into the throat of the sick person up to near his throat; then introduce a red-hot iron with fire into the concave part of the cannula.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this repeatedly, and let the patient abstain from water all day long.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a vessel full of cold water and open his mouth in it; and let him hold his mouth in the water without swallowing any of it, and move the water with his hand once every hour.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech will fall into the water immediately upon sensing it.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the patient with flies or with frankincense using the instrument which I mentioned for fumigating the throat.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this repeatedly, since it will fall by itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	The method of operation in fumigation is as follows: take a pot in which there are live apples with fire; and let the pot be covered with its cover, in whose middle there is an opening; and place the end of the instrument on that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then cast the fumigation into it, and let the patient place his mouth at the end of the cannula and close his mouth so that the fumigation does not escape until you know that the fumigation has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will fall immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it still does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient endure thirst and eat salt and garlic without drinking water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that it should come out with this treatment.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the shape of the instrument with which to remove the leech from the throat when it falls on top of itself within sight.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It resembles forceps as you see [here], except that it has this curvature which is inserted into the throat.
