Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end resembles the beak of a bird called the stork, having the roughness of a file; when it grasps something, it does not let it go entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	 Concerning the opening of boils and their incision, and their treatment in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of boils [abscesses], diverse in their formation, recalling one by one as they come to mind; namely one kind is mentioned here, and they differ in piercing them and cutting into them in two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of these kinds [of abscess] is that which is formed within itself due to the accumulation of moistures.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second manner is because of places in which it occurs from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurring on the head is different from one occurring in the anus; and an abscess occurring in a fleshy part is different from one occurring in joints; and each of them has its own judgment according to its operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And among abscesses there are those that should not be pierced unless after the maturation of pus within them and its completion; and among them there are those which must be pierced while they are still raw and do not mature according to completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as abscesses which are close to joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and extends to the point that what is around it putsrefies, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted; therefore, there is a greater cause for shortening of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or if an abscess occurs near a main member; for if you delay its piercing until it matures, it will harm either that one or through that main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or if it is near the anus, then pierce it even while immature; and do not pierce a raw abscess with incomplete digestion unless it is near the anus lest it putrefies deeply, extends to the interior of the anus, and becomes a fistula that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the right time to pierce an abscess that has matured according to completion; this is when there is cessation of pain, reduction of fever, decrease in redness and throbbing, sharpness at the head of the abscess, and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary to make the same incision at a lower point on the abscess, at its most prominent swelling. The incision should extend along the length of the body if the abscesses are located on the limbs or joints, sinews, nerves, arteries, and in all other equal places where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But for those that are reflected, proceed with the incision according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When an abscess is located in fatty tissue, it is better to delay the incision until its digestion becomes firm, as we have said according to completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before its digestion is firm, the course of the virus will be prolonged from it, and there will be much foulness and filthiness, and perhaps its lips will harden and its depth increase.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	Some abscesses are incised along the length of the body as needed, or according to what the limb requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	It is necessary to make a small incision for small abscesses and a large one for large ones; or multiple incisions similar in size to the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	There are also abscesses in which it is necessary to excavate the skin and make an incision when it has become as thin as a cloth and reached its termination, so that it is already dead; such as those that occur in many cases of swelling and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among these are those which are incised with a three-cornered cut.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And among them is one that is incised like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Such as an inguinal abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those in which a circular and crescent-shaped incision is made; similar incisions are also used for these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But those without a head, like soft subcutaneous abscesses, should be punctured with a superficial or flat incision.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when the abscess is large and has collected much matter, it should not be rushed to expel all the pus at once upon puncturing; rather, a portion of it should be drawn out.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply a dressing to the abscess until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some more of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this repeatedly in stages, until it is completely drained, especially if the patient is weak or an elderly person, a pregnant woman, or a young child, as the vital spirit is easily depleted along with the discharge of pus. Otherwise, the patient may die and you might not even realize it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, be very careful with this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after puncturing the abscess as described above, you should cleanse the wound and observe it carefully.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If the wound is small or if a flat incision was made, then apply a lint pad or an old cloth compress.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large and there are many punctures, then insert a lint pad into each one until they join together.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have excised a portion of the skin around the abscess or made an indentation in it, then fill it with old cotton, like when dressing a cloth wound or shaving lint without moisture. Then bind it for three days.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove the dressing and treat it with the appropriate ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if bleeding occurs during your procedure, then apply cold water and vinegar, after they have been soaked into a cloth, to the area of bleeding repeatedly.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the bleeding persists, then apply the remedies, treatments, and powders that I have mentioned elsewhere in this book according to their indications.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is wintertime and the abscess is near many nerves, then apply hot poultices made of linseed meal with wine and oil.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summertime and the area is fleshy, then apply poultices moistened with water and oil, or with wine and oil, ensuring that all are cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day comes, as we have said, then you should open the abscess, clean it, and administer whatever treatment is appropriate until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore all that is necessary concerning the general knowledge of treating abscesses.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	In accordance with the path of distinction, I have already spoken about every kind of abscess and how to treat each one individually.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Chapter on the Incision of Abscesses that Occur on the Scalp
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the scalp which are like nodules enclosed by their own sacs, resembling swallowed chickens' eggs.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are the fleshy ones; and those that contain moisture like mud; and those that contain a fluid like pus or mucus; and those resembling these; and there are also stone-hard ones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the incision of all kinds of these abscesses, and their removal, there is no fear, provided that an artery does not interfere with their incision.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The operation for incising these abscesses is to use the instrument whose shape is described below, called an "Introductor," until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then incise it lengthwise with a superficial incision following this shape: \[ \cdot \]
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin the incision from point B to point G. When the fluid has been evacuated, then remove the skin K that contains it, and leave none of it behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it often returns if any of it remains.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian ointment if it is available; otherwise, in water and salt. Fill the wound with it and leave it alone until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For what remains of the matter will rot.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the application of Egyptian ointment on the wound for a second and third time, and continue doing so until you are confident that no more matter remains. Then treat the wound with the ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	But if the swelling contains a fatty tumor: then cut it according to this shape, with an incision having the form of a cross. Then insert hooks between the lips of the incision and excoriate it from every part. And strive with all your strength to extract the tissue that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if an artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you afterward.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly, do the same for a hard swelling: cut it and treat it in the same manner that we have described.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision over a hard swelling is easier to perform because it contains little blood or moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain swellings among these which occur on the head of some people, with which there is absolutely no humidity.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is to say: for I once made an incision on a swelling on the head of an old woman, and found the swelling to be like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken, so that if anyone were to strike it with force, they would wound themselves.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other swellings that occur on the head, except for those that occur on the heads of children and at the roots of the ears, let them all be incised superficially.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or else make a perforation in these swellings always from their lower part, so that the flow of pus may be relieved downward.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat them with what is suitable for them in terms of treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Chapter on the Incision of Swellings in the Neck
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These swellings often occur in the neck, armpits, and groin, and sometimes also in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And among those that occur in the neck there are both singular and multiple ones; they generate from each other, and every cordlike structure arises within its own sheath, as is the case with knots and swellings of the head, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these cordlike structures.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	Among them are those that are hard like stones; and among them are those that contain fluids; and among them are the malignant ones that do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, if you see one among them that appears well disposed to the touch, which is close in color to the skin and moves freely in all directions, and is not attached to any nerves of the neck or tendons or arteries, nor deeply seated: it should be removed by making a superficial incision from its upper part downwards along the line b to the line g, and excoriate it completely on all sides; then extend the two edges of the skin with forceps or many forceps if necessary, as we have described for head swellings, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And beware not to cut any vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And use a blunt rather than sharp instrument so that your hand does not slip during the incision, nor disturb the patient unnecessarily, and do not cut anything that is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or artery and it prevents you from proceeding with the operation, then place powdered frankincense or some other absorbent powder on the wound, and bind it; let it be until the sharpness of the swelling has subsided and the wound begins to soften or shows signs of suppuration.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood absorbs the tunic. Therefore return to your operation until it is completed.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger if there are any other small cordlike structures remaining; therefore cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the cordlike structure, then it is necessary not to cut that cordlike structure from its root; rather, tie it with doubled strong thread and leave it until it falls off by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton which you have already immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for it yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the cordlike structure is cut entirely, then you must approximate both lips of the wound and stitch them immediately, after you have seen that there is no excess left.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess due to the size of the cordlike structure, then you must intend to cut its root and remove it; and perform the stitching that we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And as for those cordlike structures that contain moisture, pierce them with a superficial puncture so that you can see the location of their maturity; and place the puncture below what follows in the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply a linen strip with ointment after the puncture, and similar things to remove what remains of corruption until you see that the wound is already clean; then treat it with flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the cutting of the epiglottis due to suffocation occurring inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said that this operation is performed on the epiglottis, but I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and this is their written account.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have synanche (suffocation), the section of the epiglottis should be avoided because it will not provide relief; this is because all the veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a warm swelling in the mouth or throat or both tonsils when there is no illness in the canal, one should use the section of the epiglottis to escape from impending destruction due to suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want it, we must cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, making a small incision through its width in what lies between two circles; this incision should be made on the soft part, not on the cartilage. This place is suitable for cutting because it is devoid of flesh and the blood vessels are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the surgeon is afraid, then he should stretch the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then, after opening the skin until it reaches the canal; avoid any blood vessel if you see one of them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the soft tissue we mentioned; it is indicated by the flow of mucus from the canal along with what is cut and the loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	Therefore, when the danger of suffocation has passed, approximate the two lips of the skin wound and sew it alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines that promote tissue growth until healing is complete.
Inquit Albucasis.	Thus says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discourse which we have related is that it is not necessary unless it becomes apparent that one of these swellings has already closed the throat of a patient; and if the patient has difficulty breathing and wishes to cut the epiglottis so that he may breathe through the wound and be saved from death, then they commanded that the wound should be left open until the malady is consumed, which takes three days or more. Then they commanded that the wound be sewn up and cared for until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this is what I myself have seen: a woman took a knife and inserted it into her own throat and cut into the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to treat her, but found that she was roaring like one about to die.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Therefore, I cleaned the wound and found that only a small amount of blood had flowed from it.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore, I was amazed that she had neither cut the vein nor tied it, and yet breath was issuing from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I then took care of her wound and treated it until it healed. Nothing happened to the slave girl except for hoarseness of voice, and she returned home after a few days in better health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say that there is no fear in cutting the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the Incision of a Cyst on the Throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 42
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called a hernia of the throat is a large swelling that matches the color of the body and is common among women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it comes about in two ways: either naturally or accidentally.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, there is no innate tendency in the natural type.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind occurs in two ways, one of which resembles fatty tumors.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is similar to swellings caused by the obstruction of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is danger with this type; one should not attempt to cut it with a knife unless it is small. First probe and examine it with an introducer.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it to be like a fatty tumor and not suspended with any veins, then cut it like other tumors. Remove it along with whatever is inside the cyst, if there is one present; if not, then examine its entirety.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the site as appropriate until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On Incising over the Type of Tumors
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of tumors, and I have already spoken about all their types in the section on divisions. However, here it is necessary to distinguish between a tumor and an abscess, as there may be doubt between them.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when an abscess is hot and causes fever and severe pain until the eruption of excess fluid occurs and the decay is completed, then the fever and heat will cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When there is no heat or fever or pain and the swelling contains them, called a kystis sifachin which is a specific sack having the same color as the body, appearing like a chickpea at first but becoming larger or smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds of swellings: either fatty ones or those that contain fluid.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colors of the fluid vary according to what was said earlier under division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to treat a swelling, it is necessary that you examine it and inquire about it first using an instrument called the introductor, as will be described in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The method of examining abscesses and all swellings is to take this instrument and insert it into the moistest place that you find in the swelling. Then gradually turn your fingers along with it until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then bring your hand around according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the introductor and observe what emerges from its trail.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If fluid of any color flows out, then cut it with a superficial incision as described for other abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	But if no fluid comes out at the introductor's trail, then know that it is fatty. Therefore cut it with an incision in the shape of a cross as shown earlier. Then suspend it with hooks and remove the skin from all sides easily. Keep the kystis intact if possible so that you can extract it along with the swelling.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the kystis ruptures during the operation and it is not possible to extract it intact, which happens often, then remove it in pieces until none remains.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if some of it remains, whether a little or much, the swelling will likely return again.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it defeats you and little remains: then fill the wound at its completion with some caustic and sharp powders; and bind the wound, and place upon it what sits upon an aposteme of heat, and treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	But if there is a large swelling, then draw apart its two lips and treat it along with that which is inflamed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if you have an opposing pulsating or non-pulsating vein: then hasten, and fill the place with pulverized myrrh; leave it bound for two or three days until the wound putrefies and the ebullition of blood ceases. Then return to cutting what remains of the swelling.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning external instruments for incision and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among these are shapes of intrusive tools; they are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For among them there is a large one, and among them there is a medium-sized one, and among them there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They should be made of iron with squared ends neatly, so that they may hasten entry into the swelling.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are shapes of trial tools, and no, that is, perforators; and one of them is called beris, that is, the perforator; and they are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For among them there is a large one, and a medium-sized one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating by means of them swellings, and fistulas, and boils from that which is between them of the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and soft like large needles with which sutures are made, of citrine or of bronze or iron or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And those among them that are made of citrine are the best.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And trial tools are also made of black lead which are suitable for investigating by means of them fistulas whose concavities are reflections so that they may reflect with their smoothness together with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are again three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because among them there are long ones, medium ones, and short ones, according to the size of the width of the fistula and its narrowness.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Shape of Hooks, and they are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because among them there are simple ones, namely those with one curvature; and they are three kinds as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And among them there are blind hooks and they are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And among them there are hooks having two curvatures and they are three kinds; and among them there are hooks having three curvatures and they are three kinds; and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the shapes of knives with which knots and boils are cut and scraped; and they are three kinds: because among them there is a large one, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their tips with which cutting is done are sharp, the other ends are not sharp; and they are not placed thus except that with them assistance may be given in scraping knots when there is fear of cutting a vein or nerve: and so that by means of them the sick person may be healed, and may find a little rest from burning which he finds at the scraping of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	This is Magdalena, and it is three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of air and they resemble the ray with which distillation is performed; and at its broad end there are hidden holes like those of a syringe; and through it fluid runs inward and outward as desired.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	Shape of syringes which are hidden between the fingers during piercing of boils; and they are not perceived by the sick person; and they are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Forms of Suction Cups with which the flow of blood is cut off; and they are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of brass or glass, round, rather long, as you see; and let them be somewhat thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of suction cups are with you, large and small: so that you may cut off blood through them swiftly in case of necessity, and then when medicine is not present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use them for cutting off blood in every part of the body; and use only in fleshy places: such as thighs, hips, arms, breasts, belly, groin, and similar ones, from moist flesh.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes other small instruments similar to the bark of fisticus are made from them according to their shape; with which blood is cut off when it flows out from a place of phlebotomy, or at an incision of vein or artery: and sometimes they are made round in this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the care of Breasts of men which resemble the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men become swollen at the completion of sleep (that is, when they begin to grow during sleep) until they resemble women's breasts; and they remain offensive with abscesses.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	He therefore who detests this, it is necessary that he cut over the breasts with a crescent-shaped incision according to this shape out of line, b to line, g. Then scrape off all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with an embellishing medication.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the breast inclines downward and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that it be cut in two on its upper sides with two incisions similar in shape to a crescent moon, each of which continues with the other at their ends until there is a larger line containing a smaller one, according to this shape from line b to line g. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips and remove the fat, and apply what we have said about suturing and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not complete the incision that you ought to make because of the patient's discomfort or because of bleeding: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with cotton soaked in a corrosive ointment and leave it until it corrodes the remaining fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the perforation of an abscess that occurs under the inguinal region.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur under the inguinal region are of hard species of Struma, which contains a cyst, and among them are those that contain fluids.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those that contain fluids must be opened with a crescent-shaped incision according to this form, from line b to line g. And when all that is in the abscess has been evacuated by pus, then fill it with old cotton and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the cotton and treat it with an appropriate ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	But if the abscess is of the species of hard Struma nodes, then cut over it as we have said equally in the section on Struma.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If however the wound extends so that it discharges pus, then apply a cautery to it according to what was said beforehand.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs because of an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it becomes consolidated, then it often happens that an abscess forms there. The same happens with veins, so that an abscess and swelling occur there as well.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery or vein are these: because when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long and gathered deep within the body; and when you press on the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round and prominent on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And cutting into this abscess is an error, especially when it is located under the armpits, groin, neck, and many other places on the body. It is very large indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, it is necessary to avoid treating these abscesses with a knife, and those that are located on the extremities or on the head should also be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Thus, for those abscesses due to swelling from an opening of an artery, make a cut in the skin along its length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, and afterwards expose the artery; free it from its sheaths until it is revealed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Next, insert a needle under it and cause it to pass through until it reaches the other side, and tie the artery with doubled thread in two places, as I have taught you regarding the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the space between the two ligatures with a spatula until all the blood in it has flowed out and the abscess is resolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment that produces pus until the ligatures fall away; afterwards treat it with appropriate ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	But if the abscess is due to a cut vein, then you should hold back as much of the skin along with the abscess as possible in your hand.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place you are holding and cause it to pass through until it reaches the other side, with doubled thread attached so that you may pull it out on the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the abscess with a good ligature as I have shown you for the vein, taking two parts from both sides with two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread may come out, then insert another needle with a different thread beneath the abscess at the point of incision; press down and secure your threads at four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut through the center of the abscess until it opens up; then make an incision for any surplus skin and release what is bound within it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place on it a powder which you have soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply dressings and ointments until the wound heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	About an abscess that occurs due to twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter 1.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in the artery and vein, similarly it happens in nerves due to blows or excessive exertion, etc., most commonly at joints like elbows or heels, and wherever nerve junctions move. Such abscesses are severe.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It appears similar to the rest of the body and is usually without pain until it becomes quite inflamed when pressure is applied, causing numbness akin to stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	This abscess does not form deep within the body but is beneath the skin. It can move in any direction and does not travel forward or backward.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, those occurring at joints should not be lanced with a blade.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For it may cause contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But if one occurs on the head or forehead, use a scalpel to make an incision through the skin.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small abscess, then grasp it with forceps and cut it off at its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If it is large, then suspend it with a hook and tear it out; remove it and close the wound with sutures. Then dress it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the Incision of an Abscess that Occurs in the Belly
Caput LI.	Chapter 51
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some men have many times in their bellies and other parts of their bodies growths called "thelil," resembling fungi in appearance.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is thin, and their head is large, and their lips are turned outward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is among them a small one, and also one that greatly enlarges.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	I myself have seen a man whose belly contained two such growths, resembling fungi more than anything else: they were alike in whiteness and small root, their lips turned inward, and they were inflamed and discharged moisture constantly.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut these growths, and found one to weigh about ten and eight ounces, and the other about six. And their operation is this: if the patient is moist and the color of the growth is white and moist, with a thin root, then incise it with a broad-bladed knife, and have cauteries ready in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood flows out at its incision; therefore be prepared to cauterize it if you are overcome by the blood.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see the patient afraid and fearful of being cut with iron, then take a thread made from lead, well-made, and bind it around the growth. Its manner is as we have said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the binding of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease binding with lead whenever it presses upon the growth until it is severed and falls off by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the growth has a large root, there is cause for fear and caution in its incision, especially those that are in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless, it is possible to cut through half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat it until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not dare to cut into a swelling that is dark in color, has few symptoms, and appears foul: for it is a cancerous abscess; and I will speak more about cancer later on.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	¶ On the treatment of hernias of the navel.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A hernia of the navel may occur due to many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or it happens through tears or openings that are above the belly, and either a bubble of wind or an intestinal loop protrudes from it, just as occurs in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or it arises from blood flowing from a vein or artery, according to what was mentioned previously.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from constricted windiness within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is due to a tear or opening at the navel and there is a prolapse of the intestine, then its appearance resembles that of an abscess, with no pain; it is soft to the touch and has a varied position.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to prolapse of the intestine, then its position varies even more markedly than what we have described.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	And when you press it with your fingers, it disappears but then returns; often there is a noise associated with its return. It also becomes greatly enlarged at the entrance to the bladder and causes intense pain.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is due to excessive moisture, then it remains soft when you press it with your hand, and there is no constriction or increase in size.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then it appears as an abscess that is dark bluish-red in color.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to a fatty tumor, then the swelling is hard, coarse, and large; its size depends on the amount of fat present.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to windiness, then it feels soft to the touch.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And its treatment is as follows: first, determine whether the hernia of the navel has occurred due to blood from an artery or vein, or windiness. If so, do not attempt to treat it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and fright in that matter, as I have taught you in the chapter where I spoke about abscesses caused by an artery or vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the protrusion of the navel is due to an intestine or a hernia, then you must instruct the patient to hold their breath and remain standing upright.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then make marks with a hot iron around the entire circumference of the navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Next, instruct them to lie down on their back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then circle the navel with a wide bandage around the spot you marked with the cautery.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Next, extend the center of the swelling upwards using a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it firmly around with thread or silk cord, and make sure the knot is tied tightly.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the center of the swelling where you have extended it above the bandage.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find that it is already captured by the bandage, then extract it carefully and insert your index finger into it. Push the intestine back inside the abdomen, and if you find a hernia, then grasp it with the hook and cut its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if an artery or vein is contrary to your intent, then bind it very tightly.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to the operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and thread two strong threads through them. Insert these needles into the circumference you made around the swelling like a cross, making sure they penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tie the swelling at four points over the needles. If you wish, remove the needles and leave the area until the extended flesh rots and falls off on its own, or cut it when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with appropriate ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the navel hernia is from fatty tissue or moisture, then you must hollow out the swelling as we have described.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out blood or moisture that you find within it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat the hernia with something that will hold the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of a CANCER.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken about the division of species of CANCER and how it can be treated with medications. We have also warned against its treatment with iron lest it should become ulcerated. And we spoke about CANCER generated in the womb and precautions against its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes CANCER occurs in a location where its removal is possible, such as CANCER found in the breasts or thighs and similar parts, from which it can be completely removed. Especially when it is just beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But when it has spread and become large, you should not attempt to approach it
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For indeed I have been unable to cure anyone from this condition, nor have I seen another before me who succeeded in doing so.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation when it is located as we have described, is to cut around and solve the inflamed area with black bile occasionally.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then perform phlebotomy on it if you find it visibly engorged
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient with a preparation for the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then insert hooks into the CANCER that fit it
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then hollow it out from all sides with skin, according to your examination, until no trace of its roots remains. Let the blood flow freely and do not cut it off hastily, but squeeze the area and wipe away thick blood completely either by hand or with whatever instruments are possible at the time
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if there is difficulty in the flow of thick blood from the incision due to an artery or vein, then cauterize the vein until bleeding stops.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the treatment of Dropsy
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have now described the division of kinds of dropsy and how water collects; also signs of each kind and their treatment with medications.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And the one that is treated with iron is only a single kind of ascites; it does not approach the kind called tympanites, nor at all that called hygrosarcoma, for the latter is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	But when you have treated this species of dropsy called tympanites with medications and your treatment has not helped,
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if weakness has already come upon the sick person or there is another illness besides dropsy—for example, coughing, diarrhea, and similar ailments—then beware of treating him with iron, for it carries danger.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see the sick person is robust and there is no other illness besides dropsy alone, neither a child nor an elder: then the way of operation in this case is that you should lift the sick person standing between your hands, and your assistant behind him press his belly with his hand to push the water towards the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a pointed spatula of this shape.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It should have two pointed ends and be long, with a sharp point like a spathulum.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But let it be somewhat shortened gradually, so that you do not pierce through with it during the operation all the way to the intestine and injure him.
Deinde considera.	Then consider this:
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the dropsy comes from the intestines, then you should lengthen the incision by three finger widths below the navel directly upwards towards the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the dropsy is due to an illness of the liver, then your incision should be three fingers to the left of the navel.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if its cause is the spleen, then the incision should be on the right side; and it must not be made on the side where the sick person wishes to lie, so that the excess fluids do not flow into that weak spot.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce the whole skin with an instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert your hand with a speculum into that incision, and scrape the skin as if you were scraping it off; and the amount scraped should be about the size of a fingernail or somewhat like that.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce the skin while scraping until the speculum reaches an empty space; and this is the location of water (fluid).
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then remove it and insert into the opening an instrument whose shape is as follows.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it resembles a cannula; made of silver, or brass, or bronze, smooth and polished. Its lower part has a small opening, and there are three openings on its sides - two on one side and one on the other. Its end is cut like a reed, as you see, with an eyelet at the upper end.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water (fluid), it will immediately be drawn up into it; therefore, empty out half of it in an hour.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Because if you remove more than what is necessary from it in an hour, the sick person may perhaps die from the loss of their vital spirit; or a syncope (fainting spell) may occur that approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But remove from it according to its quantity and according to what the conditions of the sick person indicate to you through the strength of their pulse, and according to their good constitution.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then remove the instrument and retain the water (fluid).
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	This is because it is retained immediately due to the skin that retains the opening which is on top of the speculum, about which I have spoken earlier, so that you pierce it in that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the procedure on the second day if you see that the sick person tolerates it; and also remove a small quantity of water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, and guard yourself against error until only a little water remains.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you are afraid for the sick person and allow much water to remain, then treat them with burial in hot sand and much sweat in a bath and sunshine, and let them wait until they are thirsty; and treat them with drying medicines until they recover: and cauterize them on the stomach, liver, and spleen after removing the water, according to what I have described previously.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On treating infants born with incomplete urine passage.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	If a child comes out of its mother's womb and the head of its foreskin is not pierced, or is pierced too narrowly or in the wrong place,
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	It is therefore necessary to immediately assist with its piercing using a very fine spatula, according to this shape.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a fine lead peg in the hole and tie it; hold it for three or four days.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When he wants to pass urine, remove the peg and let him void.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then replace it.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	But if you do not use lead, then urine flowing over the spot may cause it to close up again.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	However, one whose hole is too narrow is treated with lead, as we have said, for many days until it widens.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	Those whose opening is not in the correct place are harmed.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	This is because in some newborns the opening is at the tip of the foreskin: therefore they cannot void urine properly until they lift the foreskin with their hand.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	And there is no procreation because semen cannot reach the womb properly: and it causes great distress.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	The method of treatment for this condition is to lay the sick child on its back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then stretch the head of the foreskin with your left hand using great force, and cut the tip of its head with a sharp needle or scalpel like cutting a reed, so that it resembles the head of the foreskin and so that the hole falls in the middle as it should.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And beware during your procedure from blood flow.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this happens very often.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	So apply to it what stops bleeding and care for the wound until it heals.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	On the Elephantiasis which occurs on the foreskin and head of the penis, and corruption, blackness, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 65.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	Often these elephantiasis occur on the penis, which is an elevation of corrupt flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And among them there is one that is malignant, and another that is not malignant.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	So you must hang the benign one with a fine hook and cut it off until you cleanse it entirely.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then place over it a cotton wick dipped in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it afterwards with linseed oil until it heals.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	But if the elephantiasis is malignant and of foul color, then you must apply a caustic after cutting it off along with its root.
