Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	But if elephantiasis is on the foreskin of an uncircumcised captive and part of it is inside the foreskin while another part is outside, then you must first remove the elephantiasis that is inside until it solidifies. Then treat the outside; because when you treat both at once, the foreskin will not be torn.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And indeed blackness and corruption also occur on the testicles and foreskin.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	Therefore you must hollow out all that has already turned black or is about to decay or has already decayed.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then apply a linen cloth over it afterwards dipped in honey that has been mixed with powdered pomegranate rind and sieved barley groats.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	If blood flow occurs, then apply a lunar cautery branding iron according to this shape.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	For the cautery is helpful for two conditions at once: for blood flow and when a wound becomes corrupted.
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	But if the tip of the wand is eaten away and completely destroyed within an hour: then it is necessary to insert a lead cannula into the opening of the penis so that the patient may urinate over it.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	But in the case of adhesion of the foreskin to the head of the wand, which indeed does not occur except in one whose foreskin is healthy and circumcision is not required upon it: and sometimes adhesion occurs due to a wound or an abscess: therefore you should scrape it off with a blunt spatula until the bond is loosened and the head of the wand is freed from all sides.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	But if it is difficult to distinguish them carefully, then you should scrape off some from the head of the wand and from the foreskin.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	This is because when the foreskin is thin, it may be quickly punctured due to its thinness.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate between the foreskin and the head of the wand with a fine linen cloth that has been soaked in cold water so that they do not stick together again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then treat it with astringent wine until it is consolidated.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	Concerning the purification of infants and the treatment of errors that may happen to them.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not the solution to continuity as other wounds are: nevertheless, since it is our operation by our will and its use is proper for boys, it is necessary that we mark a better operation and an easier path leading to health in it.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say therefore that the ancients did not mention circumcision in any of their books because they do not use it in their laws and it is only what we have acquired through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	It is because I have found most artisans and bloodletting practitioners using cleansing, circumcising with razors or forceps, and binding with thread and cutting with a nail.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	And I have already tested all these methods and found no better cleansing than with forceps and binding with thread.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	For in cleansing with a razor, the skin often slips away.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	For the foreskin has two coats of skin, so perhaps the upper one is cut and the lower one remains intact. Therefore, he must make another incision to cut the other [coat], causing pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And with cleansing done by cautery, that is, digitally, as surgeons use it, the incision of the end of the male organ is not secure because perhaps it may enter its hole.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	But with cleansing done by nail, perhaps the iron may slip and spoil your operation. And indeed, the skin of a boy is naturally short, and many are born such that they do not need cleansing, as I have seen.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	However, cleansing with forceps and binding with thread has shown me a good result because the forceps are proportionate to the incision, so that the sharpness which is above is like the sharpness which is below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	Therefore, when you press your hand [to hold the foreskin], two sharp points are proportionate and they make one incision at once. And compression is made in a similar figure, containing the skin of the penis on all sides, with which there is no possibility of error.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the way of your own operation is such that you should make him understand, especially a boy who understands somewhat, that you are only tying the thread on his penis and leaving him until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him rejoice and be glad in every possible way according to his understanding.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your prepared hands, and not sit. Hide the scissors in your sleeve or underfoot so that the child sees nothing at all of them nor any of the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand towards his buttock and blow on the skin, then pull it upwards until the head of the probe emerges.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then cleanse it with what gathers there from filth.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then ligature the marked place with doubled thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Then tie below that a little lower.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold it with your index finger and thumb while retaining the lower ligature well, and cut between the two ligatures.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then elevate the skin upwards swiftly, and extract the head of the probe.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros.	Then let the blood flow gradually (for it is better), and put powder on top. Then place on the powder a cloth in which an egg yolk boiled in rose water mixed with rose oil has been shaken.
Recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then bind it well and leave him on it until the next day. Then treat him with the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	This is the shape of the scissors used for cleansing:
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	Let the two ends be blunt and the points meet so that no branch of the nail may escape. Let the length of the two sharp parts be equal to the length of the two handles.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	The error occurring in cleansing is that perhaps the entire inner skin or a part of it escapes at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore you should stretch it out with your fingernail before the application of the ligature and cut it according to its length.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	But if you cannot hold it with your fingernail, then extract it with a hook and cut it.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	But if three days pass and the swelling around the probe remains unabsorbed, then leave it until the swelling is hot. Then remove it easily and cut it according to how it prepares itself for you, but beware of cutting off the head of the probe.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	This will not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Therefore treat it with the substances that heal wounds from powders, which we have mentioned in the book on powders. And if it is cut deeper than intended and reaches internal organs, it will still not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	So treat it as we said until it heals.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the Extraction of a Retained Foreign Body from the Bladder.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	Retention of urine in the bladder occurs due to obstruction caused by a stone, coagulated blood, pus, or flesh growth, and similar conditions, as we have discussed among the methods of treatment in division.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	And if the urine does not dissolve and you see that its retention is due to a stone already in the neck of the bladder, then it is necessary for the patient to be positioned on his knees.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then place his feet over his back and have him stretch out his abdomen from the upper part of his back. The patient should hold his breath as much as possible.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	So press on the neck of the bladder towards the posterior side for the expulsion of the stone, whereby urine is released.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	If this does not work as we said and the condition is urgent for the patient, then you must perform its extraction using an instrument called a 'syringe,' which has the following shape: It should be made of silver, smooth, gentle, hollow like a quill's cannula in thinness, about the length of one and a half palms. Its cannula should be fine at its head.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	And the method of extracting urine through it is as follows: Take a doubled thread and tie some wool or cotton at its end with a good ligature. Insert the end of the thread into the lower part of the syringe. If there is any leakage from the wool, cut it off with forceps. Then insert the cannula forcibly like a dart.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then fill the syringe with oil or butter and egg white. Have the patient sit on a chair and expose their bladder, then insert the tip of the syringe with oily lubricant made from olive oil and warm water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then gently insert the syringe into the urethra until it reaches the root of the penis.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then place the bulb above, on the side towards the navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the syringe into it until it reaches the bladder. The patient will feel that it has reached an empty space. This is not done in this order unless the path through which it goes is tortuous.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then gradually pull out the thread with wool.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	For urine follows the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then withdraw the wool and let urine flow through its path. Repeat this procedure until the bladder is emptied and the patient finds relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	On the nature of bladder irrigation with a siphon.
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When an ulcer forms in the bladder or blood congeals in it or pus hardens within it and water and medicines should be poured into it, then use an instrument called a siphon, which is shaped as follows:
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	It is closed at one end.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And it has three holes: two on one side and one on the other, as you can see.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the concave space where the piston is placed should be exactly its size without any extra space. When it is pulled back with it, some moisture will be drawn from it, and when it is pushed forward with it, it will be expelled far away, just as a siphon expels naphtha, that is, Greek fire in battle.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	Therefore, when you wish to project moistures into the bladder, insert the tip of the siphon into the moisture and pull it back while pushing the piston upwards; for the moisture will be drawn into the concavity of the siphon.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then insert its tip into the penis, as we have described for a syringe.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	And then push the moisture with it until it reaches the bladder so that the patient may feel it immediately.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The shape of a fine enema syringe used for enemas into the bladder.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	It should be made of silver or gold. Its tip should be slightly shaped like an alkahest and below it there should be a hollow where the ligature falls.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take a bladder of a ram and place in it the moisture with which you wish to perform an enema on the bladder.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Then tie it between two hollows with a strong ligature and double thread, and warm the moisture slightly over the fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the tip of the enema syringe into the penis and afterwards compress your hand over the bladder with gentle pressure until the patient feels that the moisture has reached the bladder.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	But if you do not have a present bladder, then take a piece of parchment and make it into a circle, and pierce it all around its circumference.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert a strong thread through those holes as they revolve.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle together like an apron, after you have placed within it what you wish from moistures, oils, and waters.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then tie it to the instrument, and do with it as you did with the bladder through compression with your hand until the moisture reaches the bladder.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	On the Extraction of the Stone.
Caput LX.	Chapter 60.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	I have already spoken of the division of kinds of stones and their treatment with medicines; and I have mentioned the difference between stones generated in the kidneys and bladder, and the symptoms of each; and I have spoken of the stone on which manual operation and section is performed: this stone belongs properly to the bladder, and that which adheres to the ureter. I am now narrating the latter with clear explanation and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore, that stones generated in the bladder most commonly occur in children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And among its signs is that urine exits the bladder like water in its fineness; and it appears white sand in it, and the sick person rubs his penis frequently, and labors with it, and often hangs down.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then he is raised up, and passes out with it the anus in many cases.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	And the cure of children is easy until they reach fourteen years old.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And difficult in the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	But in young people it is moderate; and in one whose stone is large the cure is easier; but if small, its cure is conversely difficult.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	Now when we come to the treatment, it is first necessary to cleanse the sick person with a clyster, which extracts all the excrement that is in his bowels; for sometimes this prevents the discovery of the stone during examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then let the sick person be taken with his feet and shaken and moved towards the lower parts so that the stone may descend to the bottom of the bladder or leap down from its high place several times.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then make him sit between your hands prepared, and his hands under his buttocks so that the bladder may be entirely inclined towards the lower parts.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then examine him externally and touch him.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If you feel the stone in space, then hasten immediately with an incision above it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	But if it does not fall with your touch at all, then it is necessary that you wipe off the index finger of your left hand with oil, if the patient is a boy; or the middle finger if he is a full-grown youth. Then insert it into his anus and search for the stone until it stands under your finger. And gradually turn it towards the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press upon it with your finger and push it towards the external place where you wish to make the incision. And instruct an attendant to press on the bladder with his hand, and instruct another attendant to stretch the testicles upwards with his right hand, and with his other hand to remove the skin which is beneath them in the part near the place where the incision will be made.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then insert the Spatulum incisium, the form of which is as follows.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And find it between the anus and the testicles, not in the middle but to the left side of the birth, and make the incision upon the stone itself, keeping your finger in the anus. And let the incision be transverse, so that it is wider externally and narrower internally, according to what is possible without making the exit of the stone from it too large.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	For perhaps the finger which is in the anus will compress the stone at the incision and it will come out without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And know that when a stone has corners or edges, its exit is made difficult on account of this.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And when it is smooth like a gland and round, its exit is easy.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore for one that has corners or edges, make an extension in the split.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	But if it does not come out thus, then you must hook upon it or use a clamp properly, the end of which is like the crescent moon that holds onto the stone and does not slip off. Or else insert under it an instrument with a curved tip.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	But if you cannot do this, then widen the opening somewhat.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	If something made of blood binds you, cut it off with a scalpel.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	But if the stone is larger than one, then firstly introduce a large one into the mouth of the bladder.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut upon it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Afterwards insert a small one afterwards; and do likewise if there are more than two.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	But if it is very large, then it is ignorance to attempt it with a large cut.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	For one of two things happens to the sick person, either he dies or a continuous dripping of urine occurs because the place does not consolidate at all.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	But remove it by expelling it until it comes out: or break it with forceps and remove it piece by piece.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	When you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with frankincense, aloe, and dragon's blood; bind it and place over it a cloth soaked in oil and wine, or rose oil and cold water to cool the hot inflammation.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then lay the sick person on their back with their head raised, and do not loosen the bandage until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	But when you untie it, irrigate the place with water and much oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphoretic ointment and basilicon ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	But if a hot inflammation with corrosion and similar things occurs in the wound, such as when blood clots in the bladder and prevents urine from flowing out, which is recognized by the exit of blood with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Therefore introduce your finger into the wound and remove that blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it provokes the corruption and putrefaction of the bladder.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, water, and salt; and apply whatever is appropriate from remedies until it heals.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And during the entire period of treatment, you must bind both thighs and press them together because of the medicinal applications placed on the location.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	If a stone is small and situated in the urethra's opening, causing an obstruction to urine flow, treat it according to my previous instructions before proceeding to perform an incision.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	For many times you will be spared from making an incision through this treatment; I have proven that.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And take aPerforator made of iron, which has the shape of a triangular tip and is sharp, fixed onto wood.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread and tie it to the urethra below the stone so that it does not retreat back into the bladder.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Next, gently insert the perforating iron into the urethra until the triangular tip reaches the stone. Then slowly rotate the iron with your hand on the stone and attempt to bore through it until you pierce through its other side.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	For urine will be immediately relieved.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand over the remaining piece of stone on the outer part of the urethra.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	For it breaks apart and exits with urine, and the patient is cured.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	But if this treatment cannot be prepared due to some obstruction, then tie a thread below the stone and another above it.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then cut into the urethra above the stone between the two ligatures.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Afterwards, untie the ligature and cleanse any congealed blood that has formed at the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to tie a thread below the stone unless to prevent it from retreating into the bladder. And another ligature above is only necessary so that when the thread is untied after the stone's removal, the skin returns to its place and covers the wound.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	§ On the Extraction of a Stone in Women.
Caput LXI.	Chapter 61.
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	A stone is rarely formed in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	But if a stone happens to any of them, then treatment is difficult and hindered due to many methods.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of these [causes] is that the woman may perhaps be a virgin.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And secondly, because you will not find a woman who reveals herself to a physician when she is chaste, or among those who have husbands.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third reason is that you cannot find a woman who knows this art well, especially the operation with hand.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth reason is the remoteness of the stone's location; therefore it requires deep incision, and there is fear involved.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	But if necessity compels you to perform this [operation], then it is necessary that you take a woman physician who knows well; and she is rarely found.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	But if you lack this [a woman physician], then seek a chaste, skilled physician and present a midwife well-versed in women's matters or a woman who understands part of this art; therefore make her present and especially instruct her to do everything that you prescribe concerning the investigation of the stone.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	Firstly, she must look and see if the woman is a virgin; then it is necessary that she inserts her finger into her anus and seeks the stone.
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If she finds it [the stone], then let her hold it with her finger and then instruct the midwife to insert her finger into the patient's vagina and inquire about the stone after placing her left hand over the bladder and compressing it well.
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If she finds the stone, then it is necessary that she gradually moves it from the opening of the bladder downwards with all her strength until she reaches it at the root of the thigh.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then cut over it at the opposite side of the middle of the vulva at the root of the thigh from whichever side you prepare her for and feel the stone in that part; do not remove your finger from the stone but hold it under it, and make the incision small initially.
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then insert a probe through that incision.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If he feels the stone, then increase the size of the incision according to how much the stone protrudes from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And know that there are many kinds of stones.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	Among them is a small one and a large one, smooth and rough, long and round with branches.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	So know its kind so that it may be made clear to you about that which you desire.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If blood overcomes you, then add powdered myrrh to the wound and hold it there for one hour until the bleeding stops.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your procedure until the stone comes out; and prepare with you the instruments that I mentioned for extracting a stone from the bladder so that they may assist you in your procedure.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	But if the flow of blood overcomes you and you know that the bleeding is from an artery that has been cut, then place powder on the wound and bind it with a suitable bandage; do not remove it and leave the stone alone, do not take it out.
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	For perhaps the woman may die if she is weak.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then dress the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When the bleeding has subsided after a few days and the wound begins to putrefy, then return to your procedure until the stone comes out.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	Section on a watery hernia.
Caput LXII.	Chapter 62.
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	A watery hernia is not merely a gathering of moisture in the white sac which is beneath the skin containing the testicle, and this is called the sac.
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And sometimes it is in its own membrane which nature has prepared for it in the part of the testicle until it bursts; this is another testicle and is the skin of the testicle between the white sac which we mentioned, and this happens rarely.
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	And indeed, the cause of this branch's formation is weakness that affects the testicles; therefore, this matter flows towards them.
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And sometimes it occurs due to an impact on the testicles.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	This moisture has many colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	Or it may be inclined towards yellow, or red and bloody, or black and foul-smelling, or white and watery; but the latter is more frequent.
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	And these are the signs by which one knows where a water gathering occurs:
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if it is in the white sac which we mentioned, then it is a round abscess, slightly elongated like an egg shape; and the testicle does not appear because moisture covers it on all sides.
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	And if the moisture is in its own membrane, then it is a round abscess with an egg-like part; and because of this, one thinks that there is another testicle.
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the moisture is between the skin of the testicles and the white sac, then it falls under sensation.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	Therefore, when you wish to know the color of the moisture, then examine the color of the moisture in the abscess by using a square instrument.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	Based on what comes out in the trace of the instrument inserted, judge about that which is between it.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When we come to the treatment with an iron instrument, then it is necessary that you order the patient, if possible for him, to undergo bloodletting, and see if his body is full.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he should lie on his back over something high, and place many cloths under him.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then sit on his left side, and order the assistant to sit on his right side, who should stretch out his virga towards one of the two sides of the skin of the testicles, and towards the part called mirach of the abdomen.
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a broad spatula and cut the skin of the testicles from the middle along its length up to near the pectin; make the incision according to the straightness of an equidistant line that divides the skin of the testicles until you reach the white siphac that encircles it: and strip off its skin and observe it, or be careful not to cut it off; and let your stripping be on the part that hangs with the egg more: and finely examine it with the stripping according to the quantity that is possible for you.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the full siphac with a wide piercing and drain out all the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with hooks, and extend the siphac upwards, and do not touch the skin that embraces the testicles: and cut the siphac however it is possible for you to cut it, either with its entirety or in pieces, especially its thin side.
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not examine carefully, there will be no safety in its incision, lest water return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	But if the egg protrudes outside its skin during your operation: then when you have completed the incision of the siphac, replace it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then join together the two lips of the skin of the testicles with a suture.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it as you would other wounds until it heals.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	But if you find the egg corrupted from another blackness, then it is necessary for you to tie the suspending vessels, fearing a flow of blood.
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with its suspender and remove the egg: afterwards take care of it according to what we have said.
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If however water is collected in two parts, then know that there are two branches: therefore cut the other part equally as you did the first.
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	But if it equals to you that it may be one operation, then do thus: afterward wipe away the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And introduce into the incisions wool immersed in oil or rose oil: and place outside wool which you have immersed in wine and oil, and spread it over both testicles and the navel: and place over them doubled cloths, that is bandages: and bind them over with a bandage that has six folds according to this shape.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	Then two cloths are taken and soaked and filled with red wool, according to this likeness: and they should be finished with cotton or wet wool at the ends with which it is pressed: and they shall be gathered together with a bandage around the loins of the thighs: and one end shall take over the anus up to the back, and the second shall take to the part of the chest, and two ends shall lie on both hips below, and two other ends shall lie on both groins, and the whole bandage shall be gathered together at the loins of the thighs.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And when this branch is artificially treated with a cautery instead of cutting with a knife, and it is such that you take a sharp scalpel cautery, and cut the skin of the testicles with it: and it is heated, according to what we have described: until when the white matter containing water appears, then take the cautery, according to this shape.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	The Greek letters are similar.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	Then pierce that white matter with it and burn it until all the moisture has come out.
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	Then stretch out that white matter with hooks and scrap it off with a fine burning cautery, and cut into it as much as you can until you have removed all of it.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And be careful not to burn the egg itself.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	And know that this operation is safer and further from bleeding, and better than the operation with cutting.
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if you find opposition at the time of cutting or cauterizing, either a hot abscess or bleeding, or something else: then it is necessary that you treat what opposes you with that treatment which suits it, according to what has been prescribed.
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	If the patient is fearful and does not await this operation because of its horror: then perform the incision according to how I describe it.
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When you have confirmed at your place through what we said about significations that the ram is watery: then it is necessary that you make the patient sit on a raised seat.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then cut the abscess in its lower part with a wide spatula and make the incision along the length of the body, and let the opening be ample until all water runs out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then put a pad on the wound and tie it, and let him go so that the remaining water runs out: then treat it until the wound heals.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	If opposition is to the exit of water at the time when you cut it and there is nothing else but because a white cloth opposes at the wound's opening and hinders the exit of water: then it is necessary that you insert a feather into the wound, or an instrument with which water is drawn out from hydropic tumors, whose shape has been described before, or add a little to the operation on the wound.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	And know that water returns and collects after six months, or approximately that time.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	When it has collected, then cut it again in the same way, and the patient will pass his days.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	[On] The treatment of fleshly rams.
Caput LXIII.	Chapter 63.
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	You should know that in cutting into this ram, there is danger leading to harm in many dispositions.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore, it seems to me that its release would be safer from it.
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I am remembering the operation on it and the appearance of the abscess.
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	I say therefore that many swellings occur in bodies from which the testicles are composed: and this happens due to many causes, namely.
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Either from an acute or harsh fluid that flows towards the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from injury.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the color of the swelling is like the color of the body, and there is no pain found in it; and it is a severe swelling.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it is a stone-like swelling, whose color is dark, and there is no sensation in it.
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it happens from a blockage of the arteries and their dilation; as has already been mentioned previously: or from dilation of veins.
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	That which occurs from them due to dilation of arteries is recognized by the arrangement of the swelling when you press it with your fingers.
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And do not touch it at all.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	But that which occurs from dilation of veins does not disperse at all when pressed with fingers.
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And now it is possible that on this appearance, incision and on the remaining flesh is done: and it is, as you separate the skin of the testicles.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then extend the testicle upwards and remove it with a white silk thread, and free the suspensiony ligament from its vessels, and ligate the vessels, and cut the suspensiony ligament after you have freed it from all parts of the testicle.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If however the testicle is adherent to those surrounding tissues, then it is necessary that you draw out the testicle and cut it.
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if there is adhesion between any part of the scrotum or what is between the vessels, then it is necessary that you free all that adhesion and cut it with a round incision.
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	But if there is growth of flesh in the place where adhesion occurs that is behind, then it is necessary that you cut all of it and remove the testicle as we have said.
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When your operation is complete, then fill the wound with wool soaked in rose oil and wine, and then treat it with the usual treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	Concerning the treatment of a broken limb, which is accompanied by a dislocation.
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	An abscess has formed, wrapped around with a certain wrapping, similar to a funnel, along with the softening of the testicles; and it becomes difficult for the sick person to move and exercise, and to walk.
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in the treatment of this ailment, there is fear, because of the memory of what preceded it.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	But it is necessary for us to say the operation performed on it according to what the first ones did.
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore that you should make the sick person sit on an elevated seat.
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then push the suspending ligament of the testicles downward.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then grasp the skin of the testicles with your fingers, near the vessels that are close to the penis; and let another assistant hold it and stretch it out forcefully.
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then make a wide, oblique incision with a sharp scalpel across the direct course of the vessels until they are exposed.
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then strip it from all sides, as we have told you regarding the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Then insert a needle into it with a doubled thread and tie it at the first points where the dislocations occur; and tie it again at the last of them.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then cut it straight across in the middle section along the length of the body, and remove what has accumulated from corrupted foul humors.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then treat the wound with the usual treatment for other wounds, so that pus may be generated to allow the vessels that nourish one of the testicles to fall away.
Non est enim malum per illud.	For there is no harm in this.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	But if all the vessels are dislocated, then it is necessary to remove the testicles along with the vessels; lest on account of the incision, the egg be deprived of nourishment and waste away or shrivel up, and not have any benefit.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	On the treatment of twisted intestine.
Caput LXV.	Chapter 65.
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The cause of this twisting is from a rupture which occurs when the intestines are extended over the abdomen in the groin region due to intestinal obstruction.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Therefore, the intestines descend through that rupture into one of the scrotal sacs.
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture occurs either due to a sudden straining or an extension of it.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis.	And these two types occur for many reasons.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from a blow.
Aut saltu.	Or from falling.
Aut clamore.	Or from a sudden outcry.
Aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	Or lifting of heavy objects and similar causes.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign is when it occurs from the extension of the straining.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It happens gradually over a long period and does not occur suddenly; it is an equal swelling towards the depth because the straining compresses the intestine.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	And its sign when it occurs from a rupture of the straining is that it causes sudden severe pain at the outset; and it is an uneven swelling appearing near the skin; this is due to the exit of the intestine and its course towards the external opening.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And sometimes it comes out with a loop of intestine; this condition is called 'twisted intestine' and 'hernia'; and sometimes it occurs with wind.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	And sometimes feces run into the intestine and become lodged there; this causes great harm to the patient, especially when it presses down.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in treating these conditions with iron, caution must be exercised to avoid accidents.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of treatment is that you should instruct the patient to gently push the intestine back into its proper place with their hand if it can be reduced.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then, make the patient lie on their back between your hands and raise their legs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then stretch the skin that follows the skin upwards and cut all the skin of the testicles along its length.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix forceps on both lips of the incision according to your need to open it with them; and let the incision be made as far as possible so that an egg can pass through.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then strip off the spermatic cord and what is under the skin of the testicles until when the white spermatic cord is completely revealed, hard on all sides. Then insert your index finger behind the testicle, between the white spermatic cord and the skin of the egg, and separate without any adhesion that is in the posterior part of the egg.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move the testicle with your right hand towards the interior of its skin and stretch the white spermatic cord upwards with your left hand. Then raise the egg with the spermatic cord towards the part of the incision, and tell your assistant to extend the egg upwards, and you dissolve the adhesion that is behind it completely.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And search with your fingers that there is nothing there of the intestine involved in the hard white spermatic cord.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	But if you find something from it, then push it down towards the abdomen below.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take a needle with a thick thread made of ten threads and insert it under the last spermatic cord, that is, the tunic which is under the skin following the incision. Then cut the ends that stick out from the thread until there are four threads remaining.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then arrange some of them over others in the shape of a cross and tie them together with the spermatic cord which we mentioned earlier, because it is under the skin of the testicles with a strong ligament, until no vessel that nourishes them can send anything to them so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place again another ligature according to the first one, distant from it by two fingers less.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two ligatures leave a portion of the spermatic cord equal to the size of your finger under the skin of the testicles and cut the rest around its circumference and remove the egg.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then make an incision in the lower part of the skin of the testicles from which blood and pus flow as we have described earlier.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply a piece of linen soaked in oil to the wound and tie it with the ligature that was mentioned.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And sometimes the spermatic cord that we have spoken of is cauterized after its incision is made to prevent bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this happens very often.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	Leave the ligature until it falls off by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	But if its falling off is delayed, then treat it with warm water and apply what was mentioned earlier until it falls off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then dress the wound with the usual dressing of wounds until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	On the Hollow Needle.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter 66
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In this needle, I have not seen anyone dare to use iron for its cautery.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And the earliest authors said that it is done like we described for the needle with a vinegar coating.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, tie the vessels after cutting them below with ease, then cut in the middle and treat with what opens it until the vessels fall off, and dress the wound according to what was said until it heals.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	On Disruption of the Groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter 67
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture occurs in the groin as we have described and a swelling appears but nothing from the intestines descends to the testicles: and if something does descend it is small and returns at all times: truly if this condition persists for a long time, a fissure forms in the spermatic cord until the intestines descend into it.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this occurs due to the stretching of the spermatic cord which is in the groin as we have said.
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is, because the spermatic cord stretches, becomes softened and develops an abscess at the site of prominence.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with a cautery, as has been described above.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And sometimes it is treated with iron (i.e., surgery), in this manner: and it should be that the patient lies on their back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then cut the location of the rupture, abscesses, and prominence with a section across its width, according to the measure of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then tie the spermatic cord tightly, squeezing what is beneath the skin until the white spermatic cord becomes apparent under the following skin.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a cautery and place it on the prominent area of the spermatic cord, pressing it until it reaches the depth of the abdomen.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then cauterize two points on either side of the prominence of the spermatic cord and connect them with a suture; then remove the end of the cautery.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut the spermatic cord entirely, nor stretch it out nor anything else, as I have taught you in treating prolapsed intestines.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then treat it with wound treatment.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	Therefore, when cutting the threads, cleanse them and restore the wound until it is healed.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	For the spermatic cord contracts and does not regain its prominence after rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And a cautery is better in this location because it is closer to healing.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	On the softening of the skin covering the testes.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter 68
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin covering the testes is often softened in some men, causing the flesh between them to become softened and making their appearance unsightly.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary for the one who is asked to treat it that he makes the patient lie on their back and cuts all the softened skin on top of the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then bring together both lips with a suture: and if you wish, first remove the excess softened skin by three or four sutures, and then make a firm suture.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then treat it with wound treatment until it heals, and remove the stitches.
¶ De Castratione.	Section on Castration
Caput LXIX.	Chapter 69
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	Know that castration is prohibited by our law. Therefore, it would be permissible for me not to mention it in this book of mine, as it is not necessary except for two methods.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One of these is so that the doctor may know about it when questioned concerning it; and also to know how to treat someone who has suffered from it.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And another reason is that we often need castration for certain animals, due to our sustenance through them, such as rams, roosters, cats and similar animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that castration is performed in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by friction.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by cutting and tearing apart.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the case of castration performed by friction, this is how the operation is carried out: Have the animal sit in warm water until its testicles soften and become lax, and hang down. Then strike them with your hand until they loosen and no longer appear to touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration by cutting and tearing apart, it is necessary that you hold the animal and press its scrotal skin with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspensory ligament and make one cut above both testicles until they protrude. Then cut them both after scraping each off, leaving nothing but a thin membrane over the blood vessels.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that done by friction because friction might leave behind some part of the testicles, which causes the animal to desire mating.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	Section on Treatment of Hermaphrodites in Two Methods
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is of two kinds among males.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them appears as a space between the two testes or on the scrotal skin between them, resembling a small vulva with hairs, from which urine sometimes flows.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	In women there is one type, which is the vulva on top of the pubic region like small scrotal sacs, protruding externally; one resembles the penis of a man, and two resemble the testes.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	The treatment for all three types — two from men and one from women — is the same: it is necessary to cut away the excess flesh until the indentation disappears.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then treat them with the usual care given to other wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	In the second type of men's condition, from which urine emerges, located on the scrotal skin, there is no operation nor any cure for it at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the Incision of Hemorrhoids and Excess Flesh Protruding from Women's Vulvas
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	Hemorrhoids may additionally appear externally, causing disfigurement and ugliness until they become prominent like those of men, reaching even to the point of sexual intercourse.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Therefore, hold the excess hemorrhoids with your hand or hook and cut them; do not cut too deeply, especially at the root, to avoid bleeding.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it as you would any wound until it heals.
