Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the enema and the patient should raise their legs up against the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	But if medicine compels him to an exit, then let him hold on as much as he can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all night long, it is the most severe in healing.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you administer an enema to him in cases of bowel obstruction and his evacuation is hastened thereby, then repeat the enema until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or sores wounding the anus, then let the enema be very fine and gentle, like those used to administer to children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a fine enema upon which the skin should be tightly stretched.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Chapter: On the treatment of head wounds without bone fracture.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken in the division regarding the treatment of wounds as befits this book, and I will now speak here about their treatment by hand and with medicines according to what remains.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore, wounds are differentiated according to the thing that causes them and according to the place where the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things by which wounds are caused are many, such as the throwing of a stone, or the cutting with a sword, knife, spear, wood, arrow, and similar other things that are numerous.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	And wounds which occur according to the parts of the body are those that fall upon the head, neck, chest, belly, or hip, and similar other members.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I will now describe the treatments for certain wounds so that I may establish a rationale and rule for the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds, since the discussion of compound fractures will come at the beginning of Chapter III.
Dico ergo.	Therefore, I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	Therefore, when a simple wound occurs on the head without bone fracture, consider if it was caused by a thrown stone or similar object and has only pierced the skin. If the wound is large and you fear that hot inflammation may result, then act quickly and perform phlebotomy at once; do not delay it. Draw out blood according to his strength, unless there is something preventing phlebotomy, especially if little blood flows from the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be performed on the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	The patient should refrain from overeating, wine, and heavy foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if something prevents phlebotomy, then reduce food intake and avoid meat and wines.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And apply over the wound, if it develops a hot inflammation, cotton soaked in rose oil alone or with wine containing styptic properties.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If you are secure from hot inflammation, then apply over the fresh wound with its own blood and not yet exposed to air, the powder I will describe later. But if it has already been exposed to air, then apply over it some ointments until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If the wound is large or caused by a sword cut or similar, and its lips do not adhere with small strips, then join them together with stitches according to what I will describe regarding abdominal wounds under suturing.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound is already exposed to bone and hangs open without retention except for a small support, then cut into it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines and restore firm flesh instead of skin. Instruct the patient to consume foods that are easy to digest, such as broths, cooked wheat, and similar items until they can be digested.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	But if you find decay in the skin of the wound and it does not adhere to the bone, then cut away all the decayed part and cast it out. Then treat the wound.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If there is an artery or vein from which blood flows copiously and it does not stop with medicines, then ask about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	Therefore if you find it uncut, then cut it with a scalpel or ligate it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if necessity requires and the aforementioned method does not work, then cauterize it until bleeding stops.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small and simple, their treatment is easy. Therefore sprinkle this powder upon them before they change in air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of making the Red Powder.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of olibanum (frankincense), two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unslaked lime. Grind all together well and sift it. Then fill the wound with this powder and apply a good dressing until it adheres well and coagulates with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it above with bandages and leave it alone without removing it until it is completely healed so that it does not break open again.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine will not be removed from it until it is healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does the job, when frankincense and dragon's blood are not available. It also performs the same function in many large wounds when it is proper to apply it and bind them, especially for fresh wounds with their own blood that have not been exposed to air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if the wound has already been altered by air, especially during summer time, then this powder is not intended for it. Therefore treat it with what we have said and apply some digestive ointments upon it, or apply poultices made of barley flour mixed with water and honey until they discharge pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then continue to treat them with the remaining treatment until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If a fracture occurs with the wound and it is small, then extract it with forceps; I will discuss the treatment of skull fractures later.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On wounds of the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter 85
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound occurs on the neck, then there is no difference in treatment between it and a simple head wound.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if the neck wound has already cut into a nerve or artery, then if it is a nerve, there is no treatment except to apply something that causes rapid coagulation such as zinc oxide and quicklime and similar substances.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they harm nerves and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not apply anything cold at all to the wound because the substance of nerves is cold and their continuity extends to the brain which is the most exalted organ; therefore, let what is used for treatment be made from gentle medicines such as chalk washed with sweet water repeatedly infused with oil or rose oil, and tutia, when it is also washed with sweet water: and other mineral stones in this manner, and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then perform suturing; otherwise, close its edges with bandages.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound has depth or a pocket of pus forms at its lower part, then make an incision in a more depressed area of it.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery has been cut and blood flow is profuse, then separate or cut it and tie it off; otherwise cauterize it if necessary.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the thyroid cartilage or part of it has been injured and the cricothyroid membrane is preserved, then approximate the skin edges with sutures over the larynx without touching the larynx itself, and reduce it to its normal position.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then support it with a suitable bandage for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments that have astringent and drying properties until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it. If there are any bone fragments in it, remove them all, or as many as you can; but leave what cannot be removed until the wound rots and separates itself from its opening and relieves the discharge.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	But if the wound is fresh, then sprinkle upon it the powder that I have described.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If however bone appears in the wound and a fistula forms, then treat this with what is mentioned in its chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Chapter on Wounds in the Groin
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a wound from a spear or knife and you see its depth, then consider this.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If breathlessness comes out of the wound when the patient sighs, know that the wound is fatal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it is not deep and is fresh with its own blood, then do not put powder on it at first, nor bind it tightly so that the blood does not remain in its depth and return to the heart and kill the patient. Rather, apply an attractive ointment to it and loosen it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if the ointment is not available to you, then put a piece of old cotton at the mouth of the wound so that it may suck out whatever liquid comes from it. And make the patient sleep on the wound so that what collects in it may flow away.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three days or more have passed since the wound was inflicted and no convulsions, palpitations of the heart, nor shortness of breath has occurred in the patient, and you see that his other conditions are good, then know that the wound is safe.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with bandages and other appropriate treatment until it heals.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is delayed and it continues to open up, know that a fistula has already formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Thus treat it according to its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	If the wound is from a cut made by a sword or knife and is simple on the surface of the chest or back, then treat it with suturing if it is large or with dust if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if the wound has already made an impression on the bone and has cut off pieces of it, then examine the wound and make haste to extract those fragments if they are separate.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separate, then leave them be until the wound putsrefies, for extraction will be easier then.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgment concerning the treatment of other wounds that occur in the remaining limbs is the same as what we have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	On abdominal wounds, prolapse of the intestines, and their replacement.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption that occurs to the abdomen is great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	Therefore, from a large disruption sometimes one intestine or several may protrude.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Hence their reintroduction becomes difficult and the suturing more urgent and challenging.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And even a small disruption can be difficult to handle due to its unique nature.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, their replacement becomes more difficult if you do not promptly reintroduce them to their place immediately after the disruption, because they swell up, open wider, and thicken; hence, reintroduction becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, a medium-sized disruption is easier to manage because it does not present the same difficulty in reducing the intestines as do large or small ones.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that there are four ways of suturing an abdominal wound.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two types of sutures are common to both abdominal and other bodily wound sutures, while two others are specifically used for other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	But these latter two methods are more suitable for abdominal wound suturing, and I will describe each one to you with its explanation and demonstration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore that when the wound is small and some intestine protrudes from it, making it difficult to reduce, then this occurs due to one of two methods.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the narrowness of the rupture as we have said, or because there is inflammation in the intestine due to exposure to cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When this is the case, then you must warm it by immersing a sponge or damp cloth into hot water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil in water purslane, cypress shoots, and spices together with the intestine until the inflammation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes wine with astringent properties may be used for this purpose; it is better than water alone in resolving inflammation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When you see that the inflammation has been resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which have been boiled irises or mallows.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For through this, its entrance will be eased along with the small object.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its return is still prevented after this treatment, then tie off the narrow part of the rupture with an instrument used for cutting hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when prepared than cutting; it should not be forced to cut after necessity and lack of instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be sharp and twisted, the other not sharp, and its tip not too fine like a stylus, but somewhat blunt; this resembles a keyhole as you see.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the wound is enlarged and the intestine enters it, then its reduction should be made according to its natural shape into its proper place if possible; for this is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	But when the rupture is large in the lower part of the abdomen, then have the patient lie on their back and raise their legs higher than their head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the abdomen, then place their head and chest higher than their lower body.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	Similarly, if there is a disruption in one of two parts of the abdomen, then place your purpose and attention always on this, that the part in which the wound is situated be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary to do so for large wounds and medium-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it according to what you prepare yourself.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then have present between your hands a pious assistant who shall hold the entire disruption with his hand and bring together its edges.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Next, remove from it for him who follows to suture some after some; and this is the common method of one stitch.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is that you should take a needle or several needles according to the size of the wound's width.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the end of the disruption a quantity equal to the width of a finger, that is, of the physician's finger. And insert one needle except where you introduce into it thread at both ends of the skin, with two ends of sinew being under the skin internally, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and now you have brought together two edges of the skin and two ends of sinew: and there are four rows made.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then draw together with double thread around the needle several times from both sides simultaneously until the two edges of the wound are brought together appropriately.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go the thickness of a finger also and insert another needle into them; then draw it straight with thread as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease doing this with him until you complete the closure of the entire wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of medium size between thickness and fineness; for fine needles pierce flesh very quickly, and thick ones are difficult to enter the skin. Therefore they ought to be of medium size in fineness and thickness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary to insert the needle into two edges of skin close together too much; so that flesh may not be cut quickly and the wound open before healing, nor stretched out with the suture, so that healing may not be prevented.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the point of needles so that they do not harm the patient while asleep; and put on them little pieces of cloth from all sides which hold the ends of needles; and let them be until you know that the wound is already healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this indeed kind of suture with needles is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For it suffices in the suture of them that one needle or two, or about those be used.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	But the second suture is common thus: gather with a suture the four ends - two of skin and two of the silk thread in place of one, with a needle on which is wound an equal thread in fineness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced these four ends with the needle, bring back the needle from the side where you began, so that the thread falls on the upper part of the wound: so that it may be a suture like the stitching of clothes, and put between every suture an amount of thickness of a finger's breadth.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	But men know this suture.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I myself sewed up a wound which had happened to a man in his belly, who was wounded with a knife and the disruption of the wound was greater than one palm; and there came out from the intestines about two palms of middle intestine, and there was disruption in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore I brought it back after his intestine had stood outside the wound for 24 hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	Thus the wound was healed in about fifteen days; and I treated it, and he was cured: and he lived many years afterwards, being active in his occupations.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And physicians judged that it would not be cured.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And it was by miracle that I did not treat it with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because there was neither ointment nor any medicine available where I was located.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	Therefore, I applied an old cloth moistened with honey water to the wound twice a day and kept washing it constantly until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I will now discuss two kinds of stitching according to my account.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And the first step in using an acute suture is to insert the needle from the outer part towards the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	After the needle has pierced the skin and traveled along the length and breadth of the entire body part, release one end of the thread on the side where you inserted the needle, and make it pierce through from the inner part to the outer part at the other end.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	Then make it pierce back from the outer part to the inner part at that same end, and release the thread on this side. Then insert the needle into the other end from the inner part to the outer part, and continue piercing until it reaches the other end. Repeat this process until the entire wound is closed.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin again from this same side, and bring out the needle along with its thread from the skin that it pierced.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then bring the needle back into that skin and its thread on the other side. Pull it out from the skin on this side again, repeating this process once more. Continue alternating sides in this manner until all edges are approximated according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	The final step of this stitch is to tie the thread like butchers do when sewing hides, so that one end of the thread remains on each side of the skin wound, alternating sides once.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second type of stitching, which Galen called "running stitch.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This method is described as being similar to the stitch used by some physicians, where they bring together all parts of a wound that are naturally fitting and apply one end of the thread to another end, while the other end is applied to the opposite side.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done in the manner that I have described for you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You must insert the needle into the end of mirrah that is near you on the outer part and make it pierce inward until its point emerges inside. Then leave two ends of thread (sifac).
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the needle around and make it pierce from the outer part to the inner part on both ends of the thread, that is on each side.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both sides again and make them pierce from the inner to the outer part on the other two ends of mirrah that are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is better than common simple stitching, and it is the stitch that comes after remembering.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also the discourse of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The abdominal wound should be sewn with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	Which means that you should insert one thread into each needle and begin by inserting the needle on your side and make it pierce through to the other side, according to the stitch used by those who repair hides evenly.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when a rupture is in the middle of the abdomen, its stitching is more difficult than that of other parts of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	But the judgement concerning the treatment of wounds is the same for all wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	Which means that when you find a fresh wound with its own blood before it is exposed to air, and you reduce the intestine, tie it off, and adapt it, then lay over it powder for cauterization.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the wound has already been exposed to air, then apply some ointment that you have present until it makes pus appear and the threads fall out and become firm.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it as you would treat other wounds until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if you do not have the medications present, then immediately apply old cotton to it as soon as it begins to discharge pus. Change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For in many cases of simple wounds, no other medication is needed.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound may communicate with the main members and cause injury, then you should take some soft wool and soak it in tempered oil or rose oil. Apply it around the areas between the groin and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	But if he feels pain or punctures or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens), then apply a warm, black, demulcent wine enema. Especially so if the putrefaction has reached the intestines and is causing a deep exitus.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what comes from the large intestine is easier to heal, but what comes from the small intestine is more difficult.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine called the ileum does not receive healing from any wound that occurs in it at all. This is because of its multitude of veins and their size, the subtlety of its body, and its proximity to the nature of the nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if what comes out from the wound is stringy and fresh, then reduce it according to your method of reducing the intestines evenly.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if some time has passed and it has turned green or black, then you should tie it with a thread above the spot that has been discolored by it to prevent bleeding.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For there are veins and arteries in stringy matter.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that tie and leave two ends of thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it. This will relieve you of the attraction and extraction of the stringy matter and the discharge of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Reminder of a wound that occurred in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When there is a disruption in the intestine and it is small, then it may be possible for it to be restored in some people because I saw someone who was wounded in his belly with a lance blow and the wound was on the right side of the stomach and had healed: and a fistula formed, from which windy discharge escaped.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I applied treatment until I was confident of its healing and did not cease to monitor it until it healed and the area solidified.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the location had healed solidly, I feared that some other illness might happen to him but it did not.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better condition than before, eating and drinking, copulating, taking baths, and exercising as usual.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And now some surgeons have said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and it is small, then it should be tied in this manner.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And you must take ants with large heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather together the two edges of the wound and place one ant with its mouth open over them
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When it grabs onto them and closes its mouth, cut off its head for it adheres and will not let go.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one and continue doing this with ants one after the other according to the length of the entire wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then close it up and stitch the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached in the intestine until it eats and heals, without causing any harm to the patient.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible to tie the intestine even with a fine thread that has been removed from an animal's intestine and attached to it after being inserted into the point.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And you should take one end of this intestinal thread and cut off a lot of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie a fine linen thread wrapped around the end of it.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert this thread into the needle and draw the intestine along with it.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it back to its place.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of stitching with ants and intestines is only a matter of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that wounds which are large or wide, especially if they involve one of the thin intestines, then there is no cure except for delicate stitching.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the treatment of fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 78
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that any wound or abscess which becomes old and chronic, turns into an ulcer, does not heal up, discharges pus continually, and is not cut off, is called universally in whatever member it may be a fistula; and we call it zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And truly a fistula is a hard, white knot through which fluid flows; there is no pain with it, and its cavity resembles the hollow of a bird's feather; and some people call it 'risati', that is, 'feather'.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And at certain times it is moist and discharges pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	Perhaps the moisture splits open at some times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this fluid is much, and sometimes little; sometimes thick, sometimes thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already mentioned in my division that any ulcer which does not heal and no flesh grows on it is due to one of nine causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these causes is either because of the scarcity of blood in the body; or because of its evil nature; or because there is hard flesh between it and around its edges hindering the growth of new flesh; or because of much dirtiness and filth; or because the ulcer itself is putrid, and the matter sent to it is of bad quality; or because unsuitable medicine was used in treating it; or because a corrupting fever has fallen in that region, as happened in Caesaraugusta, where digestion of illnesses is difficult and healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because there is one bone too many or too few.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all of these causes and signs of them, as well as their treatments with medicines, divided into sections. Now it is necessary for me to make you aware of the treatment of fistulas and goitres that occur through surgical operation by hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Therefore, know that a fistula can occur in all members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For there are fistulas that reach the major veins and arteries, nerves, or tendons; or the intestines, bladder, or some of the ribs; or some of the dorsal vertebrae, or some of the joints composed by articulation; such as those in the hand and foot. And there are also those which approach the main member itself, and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Therefore, among these fistulas, those that arise in this manner are difficult to heal and do not receive treatment; dealing with them is hard work and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if there is a fistula whose depth does not reach these places I mentioned and you hope for its healing and trust in its treatment, then take a probe made of bronze or iron (if the fistula runs straight) and explore it with that.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is twisting in the fistula, then examine it with a thin lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For lead, being malleable, yields and curves around the twists.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if the fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to locate it by use of a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore choose one of its openings and perform a clyster through it.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the liquid you use for the enema will flow towards the other openings and escape from them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then proceed to examine carefully according to what is possible for you to know whether there is a bone or nerve at that spot, and whether the fistula is deep or shallow; or whether it is one fistula with many openings. Stand on top of all this with your utmost strength, questioning the patient, discovering the pain upon compression with your hand over the area, and similar signs and causes occurring after an apostema.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	And so having stood on all that with true steadfastness, then proceed to treat according to your confidence. And consider whether the fistula is close and apparent, or in a safe location far from a joint, nerve, artery, vein, or any of the places I mentioned to you. Then cut the fistula as previously described in my account, and remove what is inside it by filtration, and the rotting flesh that grows at its opening from flesh or gland, and similar things: and treat it until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is deep and runs straight, then it is necessary to cut it deeply as much as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it of all its rotting flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply a linen bandage dipped in sharp medicaments and insert it into the depth of the fistula you have cut with the knife. Do this several times until the medicine burns away all that remains in the depths of the fistula from decay.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments that promote healthy flesh growth until it heals.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal by this method, then cauterize it as we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If the cause of a fistula is bone and you have confirmed this, then examine it and cut it according to what I have told you; if nothing prevents you from doing so regarding any vein, nerve, or main member, as we said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If bone is discovered and there is some corruption and blackness in it, then scrape it until all the corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with what will cause it to adhere until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and continues to emit pus as before, then know that you have not reached the complete removal of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore scrape over it again, carefully examine its reason and cleansing with all your strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If it heals, that is good; but if not, then know that the corruption is in a deep and distant part of the body which you have not reached.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore, there is no cure for it except to leave it to nature.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the bone is small and it is possible for you, grasp it with fine forceps that fit its size.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then carefully grasp them all with your strength and do not leave any out.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if something obstructs you due to humidity and there is no fear or error in cutting them, then cut those humidities and flesh, if they are present, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you are not prepared to remove the bones at that moment, then place something over the wound that will cause it to putrefy; and leave it until what is around those bones in flesh and humidity has putrefied.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the wound from healing.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision you made during your operation close up.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Indeed, if you fear this, apply over it, soaked in oil mixed with ground sulfur; or cotton soaked in Egyptian ointment, or any other ointment of bdellium.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moistures decay and the bones separate from them, the removal of these becomes easier, and their attraction is facilitated.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if it is a large bone, such as the thighbone or hipbone, and what has decayed in it is a large part, then shave it with the final razor until that blackness and corruption is removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is decayed in it is a large part and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to saw it off and cut it all the way up to where the corruption has reached. Then treat it until it solidifies.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you this story that happened to a man regarding his leg so that you may set it as an example and help for your own operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man around thirty years old who had pain in his leg due to a cause that originated within his body, namely from the internal parts, until it reached the leg and formed an abscess with a large swelling. And there was no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Therefore, much time passed with errors of physicians until the abscess was opened and many materials accumulated around him.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And treatment for it was delayed until the leg became fistulous and many openings formed on it which all emitted pus and bodily moistures.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore many physicians treated him for about two years, and there was no wise hand in the art until I was called and saw his leg and the materials that were flowing from those openings with great force. And all of the man's body had already wasted away, and his complexion was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore inserted a probe into one of those openings, and it reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings and found that they interconnected with each other from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I then searched and followed one of those openings until I found a bone part: and I found it rotten, already eaten away, blackened, decayed, and perforated to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	Therefore, I removed what was exposed and prepared a replacement from the rotten bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I ensured that nothing remained in the bone except the corruption which I cut away and removed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I applied a dressing to the wound with strengthening medicines over an extended period.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it did not heal.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I probed further and discovered another opening above the first one, and found continuous decay with the bone; and I removed what appeared to me from that decay as well.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted its restoration.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	So I examined it again and did not cease cutting the bone piece by piece, trying to restore it; but it was not restored until I cut about a palm's length of bone and extracted it with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines and it was quickly consolidated and healed. And this procedure and incision would not have been necessary if not for the weakness of the patient's constitution, his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him due to the continuous evacuation of malodorous fluid from him at all hours.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	Thus he was healed completely and a hard, good bone was formed in place of the missing bone. His body's condition improved and his strength returned to him, allowing him to walk without any hindrance whatsoever.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the protruding bone in the body is already broken, then it is necessary to cut it according to this method: take a ligament and tie it at the end of the protruding bone; have someone else pull it upwards; and place another ligament made of coarse wool over the first one.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie it above the flesh that is on the bone; extend its end so that you pull the flesh downward; and uncover the flesh over the place where you wish to cut, so that the knife does not wound the flesh when cutting.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone appropriately; for when you do this, it prevents the knife from cutting rotted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the cut be made over the rotted place briefly, so that there is no concavity of bone corruption; and may not appear in its appearance to the senses, and force another cutting in its place.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is rotted and not protruding, indeed continuous with its parts; and corruption is in the middle of it or in one of its parts; then uncover all the flesh from all sides completely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood underneath.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, cut it from the first side where there is corruption until the cut continues to the other side; and let the cut be according to the length of the corruption briefly, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	But if the corruption is at the joint, cut the corrupted joint itself; and cut the bone where it continues from the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuity of two joints, then there is no remedy for it except scraping off.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if corruption is in the joint of the hand or foot, then the case is very difficult indeed.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	However, it is necessary to examine how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it away and clean it according to whatever arrangement is possible for you, and correct it with whatever means you have at your disposal; provided that the vein or nerve does not interfere.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many types of knives and saws for cutting these bones according to the situation of the bones, their preparation, thickness, thinness, size, smallness, hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary that you prepare a suitable instrument for each type of operation to be performed.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require knowledge about the kind of instruments you will need, as prolonged study is necessary.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art, and an acquaintance with the various kinds of diseases: then you will be able to find for yourself what is suitable for each case from among the instruments adapted to every ailment.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I will tell you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you should have as examples to cut by and for testing others.
Forma Serrae.	Shape of Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of Another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Another shape of Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of Yet Another Saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw, if made well, should be like this.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper part be arched, and its edge sharp; let its handle be made of boxwood, and let it be well-made in the shape of a pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of Razor for Joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be shaped like the head of a star-nosed hammer, and let its points be like those of an awl.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting unless when the heads of joints are rubbed with it when they are spoiled or when the bone is broad and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of Larger Razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of Medium Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of Broad Razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of Razor with Concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of Another Fine Razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of Yet Another Razor, Curved at the End.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of Small, Fine Razor, Tapered.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of Razor Used for Cutting Bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Also form of large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a file and its end is like a saw; it is used in many places due to the reasons of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the razor which suits the reason for that which is pierced through the bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular and its extremities are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it is necessary that all which we have said concerning Razors and Scalpels and Saws be made
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the Incision of Extremities and Sawing of Bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy due to either external or internal causes.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated that corruption with medicinal care and the treatment does not help, and you see that corruption spreading to the limb without any check, then it is necessary to cut off that limb until you reach the corruption so that the patient may be saved from death or from the worse malady which is a greater loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb becomes black until it appears rotten; which fire has burned or rotted after becoming black. Unless that corruption is cut out up to that which follows it, and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, hasten with the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the bite of certain venomous creatures such as the sea scorpion, viper, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption or bite is on the extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space for corruption to spread up to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens on the hand, then cut it off from its root at the wrist and do not give space for corruption to spread until it reaches the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades further, then cut the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption goes beyond and you see it around the elbow, then death of the patient is imminent there.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer anything else besides that [i.e., amputation] as treatment is a waste of effort.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	Similarly, if corruption affects the toe, then cut it at one of its joints; but if it has reached the sole of the foot, then amputate the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it reaches the knee, then cut off the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	But if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no remedy for it except to leave the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a limb or tying it is thus: tie the ligament below where you wish to cut and also tie another above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	Let one assistant hold one ligament downwards, while another assistant holds another ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with a wide spatula until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut or tie it off.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to put a linen cloth on all parts and not to touch the healthy place with the saw; otherwise injury may be added and hot inflammation may occur.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if bleeding occurs inside during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly; or put some powder that stops bleeding on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with an appropriate ligament and treat it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that what happened to a man's foot is the same as what I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because blackness occurred on his foot with burning that resembled fire-burning, and that corruption first began at his toe until it started to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So the man took matters into his own hands after he saw that corruption was rapidly spreading on his limb with its intense pain and burning. He cut it at the joint, and he healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, that same corruption occurred on his left index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Therefore he came to me, and I attempted to draw off that swelling with what I had applied on his hand from among medicines after cleansing his body. But the swelling did not subside, and it began to spread to another finger until corruption reached his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called upon me to cut off his hand. But I refused to do so, hoping that the swelling might still subside through my care; and also feared for his life during the operation on his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's strength was greater than his misfortune.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	And when he had despaired of me, he returned to his own land. And they told me that he hastened and cut off his whole hand, and was cured.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not recorded this narrative except to serve as an aid in cases of this kind of disease, and so that there may be a sign by which it may be recognized, and according to which treatment should be undertaken.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the Treatment of Hemicranias and the Quality of Enemas with Medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
